summary: "HR Policy for University hires trumping actual real-qualification"
main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
I think now that MS has real competition, it has sharpened its focus, has become more open minded and has broadened its willingness to consider new opportunities, risks, and models, even open source which was blasphemous back in the days of mR. ballmer. 

Glad to see Satya  in charge (and ballmer long gone). Its a good time to consider MS!
cons:
Many things pop-up when you've been somewhere for decades, but one thing that I like to mention here is this HR policy, where even if you have years of industry experience, or even if you are technically qualified, yet you are treated as a college hire no matter if a hiring team might find you as fully qualified or not. 

Basically, hiring teams don't really get to see you in order to evaluate your qualification unless they have a req for a college hire. This means that you as a candidate have less opportunities since you are pushed into a smaller set of job-opening (and auto-rejected from industry-hire category), and you as a hiring team are being excluded from considering candidates that are technically qualified.

This seems insane, policy trumps qualification! 

It was like this when I joined back the end of the last century! Crazy that such an irrational policy is still the HR mantra.

I can  whine about stack ranking and such, but many people have in the past, so I'll let it go.
advice_management: Assuming you want to hire qualified candidates, then demand HR to stop filtering  your evaluation of candidates based on being fresh out of college (mind you, even for 1 year after graduation). You should use data driven policies, not left over policies from decades ago.

summary: "Decent place to build a career with a high ceiling"
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
1. Hundreds of projects of various size and maturity. 
2. Each group is different, some feel like startups and some feel like institutions
3. Very low friction for moving between teams or groups. Escape boredom or bad coworkers with ease.
cons:
1. No standardization around compensation, level expectation, or interviews. Every group or team just does what they want and they don't trust anyone else to be as discerning as they are.
2. The enormous size of the company means there's a lot of layers of crap to break through if you want to be a rising star.
advice_management:
Standardize and centralize interviewing. 
Make rewards based on earning "points" or something through-out the year instead of a manager setting that stupid slider once or twice a year.

advice_management: The current hiring policy around diversity/external hires is killing morale. good candidates are turned away because they don't check a box.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Company has a good culture, with lots of good people.  Provides good facilities and employee resources to get the job done.  Well known name that looks good on your resume.  Work life balance is outstanding compared to the large alternatives.
cons: Being so large, if you really care and want to make an impact, you are going to bump heads with others that may not be as motivated.  Agendas are everywhere and you can find yourself on the bad end of a reorg.  You can find better benefits at competitors.  Transformation coming from top down can be very disruptive and silos below impede real innovation and change.  Bonus/Compensation is bound by budget and found little meaningful (as in $) difference between being "above average", and "killing it".
advice_management: Teams need to be shaken up periodically to break down silos and force individuals to grow.  Risk aversion has a place in Enterprise IT, but when you are the leading IT for MS solutions, you need to temper that with helping validate and push the products forward.  Needs some startup flexibility and characteristics to innovate, or the entire company will always be chasing the latest trends.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros: Great concept for cloud services.
cons: Microsoft Azure division is starting to mandate you live in Redmond.  Not really understanding this as this is the cloud services division on Microsoft and there #1 sales point is with the cloud you can be anywhere and access your information.
advice_management: you are loosing lots of talented engineers.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
A lot of good people to work with who want to GSD. Microsoft needs to find these people and promote them quicker.
Management is looking at turning the company at large around, and it is really working. It is a big ship, so it does take longer than some can handle.
Good focus on career management and good opportunities for training/personal development.
In the right department of this huge company, there are great career opportunities, and a good chance to make a big impact. Right now the right departments seem to include Azure and the non-Windows portions of Office. LinkedIn might be interesting soon as well.
cons:
I can only speak to the Windows group, so the following should be taken with that caveat:
Not quite up to par as far as smaller, scrappy companies. Too many PMs running around trying to "add value" while a lot just scrape by doing the minimum. It's easy to step on toes if you want to make an impact, and it's annoying to watch others just coasting and getting the same salary.
Similar to the PM group, Dev and QA folks can be really hit or miss.
Accountability is something that seems to be lacking. KPIs are rarely tracked after a product ships, and any mishaps are just hushed.
Benefits like free lunches, booze, and good coffee are not found here. I really don't know why, since it wouldn't cost the company much and would significantly improve the culture and retention, but Microsoft seems to be stubborn in this regard.
advice_management:
Cut down the number of PMs in the Windows group. There are seriously way too many, which means each PM is only reaching a fraction of their productivity.
Hold all disciplines accountable for the features and code they ship. Actually look at KPIs for PMs, and track bugs for the Engineering team. If people jump teams, make sure accountability follows them.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft part-time for more than a year

cons: Poor communication within management, plays favorite, not a way to move up to corporate no matter how much they tell it is a stepping stone.
advice_management: Playing favorites and doing things behind people's backs will result in karma. The environment seems bright and promising at first but it can easily take a dark turn.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Lots of smart passionate people. Technology created here touches 1 billion people. Employees donate lots of $$$ to charity and Microsoft matches.
cons: Diversity hires slow down process. Had to turn down awesome candidates to fit this.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 8 years
pros: The Microsoft Store team is very unique within Microsoft. We sell all Microsoft (and select third-party) consumer-facing products, and we get to work directly with our customers (B2C). This is the "front line" of our consumer business.
cons: The executive leadership at Microsoft Store could use more customer centricity and less of politics. The latter has been getting in the way of true growth and innovation.
advice_management: Get a leader who truly understand and appreciate ecommerce to lead. The market is clearly shifting towards online globally so without strong leadership to guide innovation, the online store is just suffering and falling behind.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Very strong CEO with vision. Good benefits. One of the best work life balance.
cons:
Less on cash compared the Facebook and Google.
Too many useless program Managers are speedbumps for important projects...
advice_management: Trim the fat. Too many employees who are simply surviving. Reward the employees by impact and not refactoring an old code. Minimize the PM:DEV radio.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than a year
pros: Good benefits, good product strategy in Cloud and future direction.  If you're content to make so-so money in Sales, and like big company internal complexity, this is a good place
cons:
No real sales commission plan.  It is an annual bonus plan that is complex, very hard to understand, has both a soft and hard cap, and has a degree of subjectivity that can be risky depending on your management.  Also, inflexible.  You may be "asked" to cover something that you will wind up spending lots of time on but not get paid for.  Marketing for enterprise business solutions is very weak, mostly focused on collateral with corporate banalities that have little value.  Licensing very complex and leads to much time spent on customer satisfaction issues. 
Microsoft does not appear to want highly agressive type "A" salespeople, and maybe they just don't need them.  Hence, the comp plan.

 But, as I said, if you are OK with OK money and the caps, etc, go for Microsoft.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 8 years
pros: A lot of opportunities, big company, varieties of cultures and teams
cons: too much politics, promotion is not totally based on your hard work but how much influence do you have
advice_management: fire talkers and politicians, promote real hard workers

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time
pros: Learn cutting edge technology.  Bias for younger employees.  Decent pay and benefits.  Good to place to learn but do not get too comfortable, the 'up or out' culture continues.
cons: Lousy treatment to people.  Constant churn.  More than one resource was fired over Skype for Business - very impersonal.  Senior Managers and Exec leadership simply do not listen - Ivory tower syndrome.  One consulting resource had to work 3 projects to just met utilization target of 40 hours/week - actual hours worked to accommodate travel between client sites > 60 hours/week.
advice_management: People do matter.  Do not forget that people made the company great - we do not have expensive CNC machines or fancy imaging machines.  People in large numbers are getting disillusioned and Amazon + Google are likely to eat large shares of the cloud and Office business respectively.  Top heavy in Microsoft consulting with too much oversight/governance and few people solving real technology problems.  Slow decision making across all businesses.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Microsoft offers the opportunity to work with some of the most talented individuals in the tech world and with some of the best technologies.
cons: Unfortunately Microsoft like so many corporate entities confuses success as an individual contributor with having the skills and disposition needed to be a successful manager.
advice_management: A majority of managers at MS have never held the position before and are given no training on what being a successful manager looks like and ultimately the rank and file employees are subject to the 'learning on the job' of most of the individuals who should not be managers in the first place. Microsoft needs to have a management training path for people prior to just 'crowning' them as managers as that results in the same bell curve as they use for stack ranking employees; 70% of managers are ill equipped, 10% fail miserably (at the expense of good employees) and 20% are decent to good, not a great report card by any account.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft  for more than 3 years

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time
pros:
They provide many opportunities to learn about software development at a larger scale.
You will work with many very competent colleagues.
cons:
They created a dog eat dog culture with the old archaic review system.
This will take a long time to flush out of the organization as it is heavily ingrained.
There is poor to non-existent collaboration between many groups and divisions causing poor efficiency.
Employees are gaming the system and the frequent moves to new teams causes lackluster productivity over time.
advice_management:
It's time to realize you don't rule the software world anymore.
If you can focus on what is important, your employees can deliver.

summary: "Microsoft is a good place to work"
job_title: Current Employee - Senior Software Development Engineer
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
Work on cutting edge tech

Takes care of health!

Good perks like - 3 month parental leave, no dress code

Broad spectrum of tech teams - to move around & try
cons:
All teams are moving towards Services model - so, core engineers will need to be on-call 24/7

If you perform very well - this company is not for you - performance model is completely flawed - designed only for avg. employee's. True high-performers gets peanuts as perks.
advice_management:
Great direction by Satya!
Microsoft recently woke up from the long dream it used-to-be-in, after Satya took charge and is steering towards reality. Great Progress!

Recent past, I was disappointed to see it continuing to produce crap & loose brand value - like - Microsoft Band. And some stunts like Microsoft phone continuum, android app platform on MS phone - fears me -  that MS is taking a U Turn back to 2012 times.

Overall, the employee headcount of many teams at Microsoft Need to shrink more. The ratio of actual employees - to the required number - of many teams is insanely high. Some teams have full-time engineers doing - build work :(.

Talent retainment needs to improve. Many good developers, who are owning core components are moving out due to poor rewards - these positions are just not replaceable.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
You _can_ have a healthy work-life balance.

Able to ask product teams and get authoritative software and design answers.

Free soda!
cons:
Open-office floor plan is metastasizing across the company.

You sacrifice career opportunities to maintain work/life balance.

advice_management: If you learned to manage under BillG or SteveB, make sure you're not still using that outdated management-by-intimidation approach.

summary: "Great people, great products, doubious management ethics"
main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Work on exciting tech and products, with truly talented and nice people.
Good pay and benefits.
Be pampered by all the advantages of working for a large enterprise.
cons:
In recent years, developed an impersonal, 100% business-driven, approach to HR and people. Prior to the wave of layoffs I was part of, many of us older employees (I've confirmed with others) were "managed out" - given bad review results that did not match the 1:1 feedback we got from everyone we had worked with. Then, during my last week before I was laid off, I was blocked from seeking an alternative internal position (the hiring manager was hinted to stay away from me) - even though I was looking outside my division and for a different type of role.
Bottom line: Either you are exceptionally excellent all the time - or you're constantly at risk.
advice_management: Care about your people at least as much as you care about your customers. Employees are both your greatest assets and your ambassadors.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Diversity in product offerings, people, and opinions. Access to amazing people, but talent appears to be gradually getting diluted. On campus shopping, restaurants, banks, etc. Wonderful sports in spring and summer.
cons: Politics appear to be on the rise. Competing priorities, duplicative efforts, and lack of coordination across teams. Easy to get lost and loyalty to people is becoming more important than loyalty to the company.
advice_management: Watch your employees back and make sure their development is your top priority. Too many managers are busy feeding themselves, leaving employees to find creative ways to advance. Employees gravitate towards short term results and opportunities for visibility. Team priorities emphasize local maxima over global benefit.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Plenty of different projects to work on, you should be able to find your niche. Good compensation, easy parking, short commute if you live on the eastside, on-site health clinic and tons of other amenities, membership to the Pro Club which is the best possible gym, a culture that cares about its employees and the betterment of society. You can use Windows and .NET for your development.
cons: Located on the eastside which isn't great if you live in Seattle, potentially lots of bureaucracy, many floundering products, doesn't often feel like you're working at the forefront of the industry. IT has created so many hoops for authentication to internal sites/email/etc. it's a real PITA.
advice_management: Give up on Windows Phone. Get rid of under performing projects BEFORE half the people quit out of disillusionment. Replace the free soda with free healthy drinks/snacks!

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
Reasonable expectations for work/life balance
Excellent salary
Great working environment - standard large corporate advantages and perks.
cons:
If you break any rule - you are gone
The salaries of HR personnel are paid by the company - so they really don't have your best interests at heart. Act to protect yourself.
advice_management: Management is a huge weakness because Microsoft does not train its managers to be managers. In consequence, you hear about (and occasionally experience) outrageously poor managers and bad management decisions. Your choices range from suck it up, to leave.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than a year
pros: Not very demanding work, good salary, some of the people were very nice. My manager was amazing.
cons: Some of the people were horrible and getting promoted for all the wrong reasons. There was a feeling that if you weren't prepared to stay on the team for 20 years, you weren't really devoted to them, a stance I hear is from the 1980's. A lot of bs in middle management and Satya has a lot of work ahead of him. This all varies by team so your experience will probably be much better.
advice_management: Try to make sure why people are getting promoted. Sometimes an entire team can be bloat, from the lead down.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Big player in the cloud space, excellent resources for career growth, has recently become relevant and respected again in the tech community, solid benefits, relatively smooth development experience if you're a fan of things like Windows and Visual Studio, many opportunities to work on products that impact millions of users worldwide, sensible attitudes towards embracing diversity and inclusion, embraces growth mindset ideals, excellent work-life balance for many teams
cons: Salary and benefits are competitive though possibly a little lower than some other big tech companies (better than Amazon but less than Google or Facebook), culture can at times feel a bit rigid when dealing with cross-team boundaries, some teams have large legacy codebase and requirement to retain backwards compatibility
advice_management: Reinstate more accessible training materials (e.g. lectures, workshops) for junior employees, improve new-hire experience (should be able to be productive first day instead of blocked on slow permissions requests), publish aggregate MSPoll (internal workplace poll) results for each org for internal employee perusal

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time
pros: Good salary, good vacation, good stock options, good promotion opportunity, and you can focus all of your time developing expertise around just a few products.
cons: On the other hand, focusing on a single stack can grow boring over time.  But I wouldn't let this stop me from recommending a job there to a friend.
advice_management: Advice to Microsoft management?  God, where would I even start?  How about realizing that it isn't 1995 anymore, and you're going to actually need to develop some goodwill with the consumer if you want to stay relevant.  One look at Windows 10, though, tells me you just don't get it.

job_title: Current Employee - Senior User Experience Designer
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Scale and scope of business provides a rewarding experience, individual impact and immense career opportunities over most other companies
cons: Internal leadership politics, challenging engineering constraints and lack of cross divisional alignment makes it incredibly difficult to produce high quality products.
advice_management: Remove the layers of management. Provide more accountability and trust in IC's.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft  for more than 3 years
pros: Company has clarity in strategic direction, culture and ambitions. Very positive under Satya's leadership
cons: Changing a culture at a company this size is turning the titanic - it will take time
advice_management: Remember you are often more in the know than the average employee - take the time to bring your teams up to speed.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros: You get to work on big projects that affect millions of customers. The company is making the right moves to increase its share of the cloud software market. You will not be bored; you can't hide out in any safe teams.
cons: If you work on a cloud service, prepare yourself for 24/7 on-call support duties. These were the most stressful and least rewarding parts of my job. After the company got rid of the testers, the devs did not pick up the slack. We're all DevOps now, after all. And we and our families pay the price in 3:00 AM calls, when you can't think straight and the pressure is like none you've ever felt.
advice_management: Bring back the QA roles, even if you don't call them SDETs. We catch far too many problems in production.  We create too many alerts that catch problems too late, and then no one reads the thousands of auto-generated E-mails anyway.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
1. The job comes with good benefits.
2. Due to being a larger company, there is opportunity to move around laterally to find a position that fits you, but you have to be very proactive about it.
3. Good work/life balance. Most benefits seem somewhat catered to family people who don't want to work late.
cons:
1. It's very difficult to "stand out" and move up in the ranks.
2. There doesn't seem to be a very good way to advance your career without moving into management.
3. The job can end up being very political.
4. It all really depends on your team.
advice_management: There should be more opportunities for talented people to move laterally, and advance their career without going into management.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Benefits; good salaries; lots of flexibility in terms of work/life, chance to work in really cool projects.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Inclusive work environment, understand the importance of work-life balance, good benefits and salary.
cons: Too many reorgs which can suddenly terminate a position. They do provide some assistance with finding another job but once a position is terminated due to reorg, you are basically on your own.
advice_management: Show a little more concern about employees that have been around a long time whose positions are suddenly terminated due to reorg and which is no fault of the employee.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft  for more than 8 years
pros: If you can imagine it, you can likely make it happen.  If you are a great collaborator and influencer, you can be successful here.
cons: Lack of strong management capabilities and senior leadership who reinforces poor behaviors by not addressing bad managers. Manager isn't a job unto itself; mid-level managers still have ~90% of their review based in their individual contributions.
advice_management: Find a way to let really smart people advance without being people managers and start growing people management capability early in career, before you move someone into a people manager role.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for less than a year
pros: Some of the best people I've ever worked with in a fun and collaborative environment.
cons: Too much red tape. Very difficult to get even small projects completed quickly and efficiently.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros: Provides you with an optimal environment to do your best work and the large size of the intern program makes it easy to make connections outside your team/product.
cons: Large company which can make it very hard to see the impact of your efforts because you are a very small part of a large entity

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft part-time for more than 3 years

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft  for less than a year
pros: Incredible company vision and culture since Satya Nadella came in and almost infinite career opportunities once you're on the inside since the company is so large, penetrating almost every market in the world and the product range is quite diversified. Never feel pigeon-holed in your role, and management is always pushing you to upskill in new areas and grow your career.
cons: Tools are broken and fragmented. I understand KM is difficult beast to tackle in a large and old organisation, but it's now impeding on our ability to actually deliver.
advice_management: Cut the ridiculous amount of metrics and consolidate the tools - before you add anything new, consult with the individual contributors first.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: I loved the culture of the company. I love learning and I loved the new challenges.
cons: They are in a really chaotic place right now trying to reinvent themselves and good people new and long term are being laid off.
advice_management: Before you lay people off make sure you know what they owned and you are ready to cover what they had or you can end up in a bad situation.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros: Challenging problems to work on. Good pay and benefits. Great development tools.
cons: Work life balance is tough to maintain when constantly under pressure of meeting deadlines. At times personal agendas get in the way of doing what's best.
advice_management: Walk around and talk to the people in the trenches. They can give you a more realistic view of what is happening in your department or division. Get the people who develop the products more in touch with the customers.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years

summary: "A Great Company that can be greater if......."
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Great Benefits 

Work-Life Balance: They stick to this promise as much as possible, even still making the attempt when business causes the request for increased flexibility from the employee during busier times.

Learning And Career Development Opportunities: Many areas of the business that allow for increased knowledge of how the technology business works and help with career development when time makes it available.

Opportunity to see and work with the latest and greatest technologies out there.  

Alot of networking face-time with industry partners both big and small.
cons:
When it comes to career advancement, sad to say the stack system is still ever so apparent. Alot of times, advancement either becomes a who you know or cultural bias. Alot of people do not want to say it, but trust me, it is there. 

Sometimes, as said above, this can lead to a career development stall with your reporting supervisor. In some areas, there is hidden favoritism being played with groups of staff.
advice_management: No matter race, gender or who that particular staff member is "buddy buddy" with, great talent (or rising stars if you will), is exactly that, great talent. Develop them to be an even better asset to the business, and give them the same opportunity to advance and grow as everyone else, making an even playing field. This is something that plagues the industry as a whole, so don't be part of the whole, be different and set the company apart from the rest.

summary: "Extremely political to the point that it is severely hampering business potential"
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than a year
pros:
-work life balance
-good pay
-brand 
-SOME good, smart people
-learning opportunities
cons:
-some pretty crazy managers
-if you are friends with the SLT of your group, you are promoted 
-managers with very little proven merit 
-politics are literally insane. You will spend nearly 2/3 of your time playing the internal game. Your internal brand exceeds the importance of your external (client brand). The same people get all of the recognition. It's almost like a high school culture
-you will literally have to sell your soul to move up within the company. Proceed with caution
-if you are creative the culture may stifle your creativity 
-the vision and TV commercials sound and look great but it's a whole different story in the trenches
-if you have genuine passion and love for what you do, and are on the fence with other offers or opportunities, go elsewhere.
advice_management:
-consider talking to the folks who get little attention at the upper levels yet consistently produce results or create new things
-ask yourself who the most customer obsessed yet unspoken of heroes are and promote them or they will leave
-diversity and inclusion still has a long long way to go despite all the marketing and investment around it

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great benefits for the whole family
cons: No budget for employee training. Employees must learn and keep up with new technology on their own and on their own time. Many job descriptions include "We need somebody who can hit the ground running", or somebody who is a "Self starter", which basically means that there is no help available and we don't have the time or patience to train you .....
advice_management: Encourage employees to be able to move around within Microsoft so that they can have a healthy career and continue to learn. They can facilitate this by actively giving them training to go from one job to the other. People should be encouraged to be able to show and share their job aspirations with their fellow coworkers and managers and not have to hide such aspirations, especially from their managers (which is the current culture).

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than a year
pros:
+ good benefits
+ travel if you want it
+ can work remotely without issue
+ huge company security
cons:
- Ambiguity is pitched as a bonus and a challenge internally...the problem is, at least in recruiting, ambiguity wasn't the right word. Lack of direction from disconnected leadership and nearly monthly re-orgs in certain divisions equated to sloppy business.
- A lot of turnover in the leadership ranks of the company as well as recruiting organization. Lose one or two here and there and that's the cost of doing business, but lose handfuls of high level people within a few months time and there is something else going on entirely. My experience was the latter.
- Innovation is at the core of Satya's principles and is on just about every powerpoint deck, the problem is though, with hundreds of thousands of employees it'll probably take 10 years for meaningful change in the way business is done has been solidified across the company. He took over in 2014, the bad old habits of sitting on the cash pile still plague innovation in 2017. This isn't an indication of bad leadership by Satya, he is great, but there needs to be more strategic changing of the guard in key areas across the company to speed up the process to remain competitive and breed thought leadership.
- So much of what managers are brought in to do is handcuffed by the Director level employees (at least in recruiting) that ideas from those closer to the work rarely are considered or even heard. Essentially, the political game of who can speak loudest to be seen is still very much in play, rather than getting the most from those they hire.
advice_management:
From one manager to those in management...I joined Microsoft because of Satya's vision and the thought that recruiting had finally turned a corner from the stereotype of old Microsoft ways. In a lot of ways, the corner has been turned but far too sharply and now you have an organization far too centralized that scale isn't an option, innovation is by consensus and the perpetual decades old issue of resourcing teams with far too heavy a vendor population against ever reducing budgets. 

My advice to management from someone who was in a management role but never really allowed to lead is to unleash you managers to do great work. If you hire them, let them showcase their skill set, which includes owning team budgets, hiring how they see fit, building strategy, building their own recruiting eco system...essentially create a builder/innovation management team, don't just talk about it. Most of all, do not separate sourcing and recruiting, the amount of friction between functions that are part of the same overall function is toxic. Lastly, because one's title isn't a Director or higher does not mean that they don't aspire to be at that level or can't do a ton of great work, you just have to truly let them without the politics in play. People join companies, they leave managers. Don't be managers, be leaders and invest time in your teams and the rest will take care of itself.

advice_management: One Microsoft means One Microsoft - abolish technical interviews for internal transfers, do not tie promotion prospects to length on a specific team. Also, let us come up with the products of the future (HoloLens, Xbox, Azure, etc.) instead of trying hard to imitate things we will probably not catch up on in a timely manner (e.g. phones, fitness trackers, etc.)

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Smart people. Opportunities for development.  Access to resources.  HR tools to really understand the value of your compensation and benefits and how to invest your 401K. Very professionally done  annual training process's and requirements.
cons: Re-orgs and layoffs. Annual layoffs are a real concern.  Must manage your career carefully to avoid these.
advice_management: Continue the ongoing focus on people.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Free soda is still in play, stock price on the rise, lots of places in the company to work if you're not happy where you are.
cons: If you're not happy where you are and have less than stellar reviews, moving between divisions is tough.  Work-life balance used to be talked about a lot - it's not talked about anymore.  Shift in culture from consumer products to enterprise products shifts the focus towards a different set of customers, which causes a lot of stress when you tell friends you work for MS and they start complaining.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft part-time for less than a year
pros:
- Great benefits
- Good Pay
- Management sometimes tries to make work fun by throwing get-togethers and getting catering
- Learn a lot in your first few months
cons: - Numbers, numbers, numbers. When I first started as a Product Advisor I wasn't told/aware about how number-centered the entire store was. Every morning we go over numbers as well as every night. If your sales were doing poorly or even if they were going well you'd get a meeting with one of the managers who'd basically berate you and make all your successes feel worthless. There were very obvious cliques and some of my coworkers were blatantly racist against me. Constantly stayed past the hours I was marked for, and was strongly suggested by management to not go on any breaks otherwise you'd get talked to or on a manager's bad side. If numbers and micromanaging wasn't shoved down our throats every waking moment I probably would have loved working here. Very long hours, 9 hours was typical and you almost always stayed past your assigned time.
advice_management: Stop micro managing and shoving numbers down our throats. You say you want it to be a fun place to work, then actually make the employees feel good about themselves. Very hypocritical place.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft
pros: Relax worry free. Potential for future
cons: Team members are unprofessional and unhelpful

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft
pros: 50% 401k match. Free coffee. Sports memberships. Laid back atmosphere. I would highly recommend this company. Work life balance is not only respected, it is encouraged. My experience has been great.
cons: I have heard that there are some teams that are not great although I've never met anyone working for said teams. Everyone I've met likes their team. You can always switch teams if this is the case. I wish they the free coffee wasn't starbucks but some fresh local roasted coffee. Minor gripe.
advice_management: I dislike open offices. They do encourage communication which is great when starting, but after that, I would rather have an office, even a cubicle would be nice. Satya is great.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for less than a year
pros: Microsoft is an amazing company with a diversity of businesses that is impressive. Colleagues were friendly, and got ample responsibility from the start.
cons: It can get a little bureaucratic at times. I felt that I was stepping on toes sometimes when I tried to take on more responsibility.
advice_management: Reduce the ratio of PMs:devs, give them more opportunity. Encourage entrepreneurial behavior among product people.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros: Great company, awesome people to work with
cons: Too slow for changing world

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros: The benefits and pay are amazing, if you get in the right group you will thrive.
cons: There is constant reorg's, I have 4 managers in 6 months.  Never got good traction to finish anything that I started.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft  for more than 5 years
pros: Great team members and projects can be interesting challenges (but dated, mostly refactorings or copying existing competition features)
cons: Managers are only lifers that were hired from college. Tech is still decades behind the competition. Change is slow.
advice_management: Fire the PMs and Middle managers

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros: Smart co-workers; customer focused; decent perks
cons: Constant reorganizations at the lower levels and none at the middle level management; still a long way to go
advice_management: Take a hard look at the middle to upper management layer; too much redundancy and lack of accountability

main_text: I worked at Microsoft
pros: Excellent work life balance. You can work from home. Great benefits
cons: After 2008 the benefit package change and now you have to pay for medical insurance.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Microsoft really cares about their employees
cons: Pretty big place, so expect some process along the way
advice_management: Keep going.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Microsoft really cares about their employees
cons: Pretty big place, so expect some process along the way
advice_management: Keep going.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than a year
pros: Working in a fast paced environment with the opportunity to experienced advanced & evolving technology at work. There is never a time to feel bored as changes is the only constant in this company ! Flexible working culture allows employees to have work-life integration.
cons: Flexible working culture also calls for having to respond to emails on the go (remotely via mobile phones), attending conference calls outside of office hours hence blurring the segregation between work and personal life.
advice_management: Nil

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Excellent culture. Have the right personality and you will immediately be a good fit.
cons: Needs to have more recognition for contributions.
advice_management: More positive feedback should be highlighted.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Good benefits and good line item on your resume.
cons: Clicky, poor management skills and ethics, dismisses harassment claims, limited teamwork and collaboration - if you like sink or swim on your own private island, go for it.
advice_management:
Train managers to manage well and fairly, don't just promote them because they're friends or have been engineers for ever but can't manage.
Take harassment claims seriously and act on them rather than just dismiss them because they're against one of the "cool kids".

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros: The benefits are really great
cons: there is no diversity in the workplace

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Good work/life balance
Many projects with high impact
Lots of options to move around, work on different things
The needle has definitely moved from "not relevant" to "worth a look"
People are very respectful of each other
cons:
Still plenty of political crap
Can be hard to retain the best people
Good people are leaving for better pay elsewhere

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than a year
pros: Flexible hours, ability to work from home, incredible benefits, good w/l balance, treat employees well
cons: Takes a while to get promotions.

summary: "Good for work life balance, bot too much political"
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years
pros: work life balance, profits, etc.
cons: political work, guys who can speak more is better than do more

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Pushing out old thinking mentalities - fresh perspectives
cons: Still pockets of alliances but seems to be more limited.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros: Good health benefits and compensation
cons: Low sock for junior level of developer position

summary: "Perfect place, if only we could stay the course on our initiatives without reorganization"
job_title: Current Employee - Principal Group Program Manager
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Autonomy, meritocratic approach, huge opportunity for impact, and incredible benefits.
cons: Constant change in reporting / team structure.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft  for more than 8 years
pros: Excellent compensation and benefits. Lots of interesting projects and ability to move around the company. Fantastic work/life balance around most of the company. Be part of something big - scale is "built-in" to everything.
cons: Housing is expensive and traffic is a pain. It's a really big place so new projects can feel slow since all the ducks have to be in a row before things take off.

summary: "Microsoft is a great place to work"
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft
pros: Great benefits, most people are awesome
cons: Internal politics can really slow you down

summary: "Great company to have long career with great benefits."
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Medical benefits, Selection of teams, Managers who understand work-life balance, Smart people.
cons: Stock compensation is significantly lower than other competitors.
advice_management: Reduce the number of PMs. Everyone knows Microsoft pays less than other big companies and most are studying interview questions to move to other companies because of small compensation. Ironically, principals don't want to move as their levels are not highly regarded at other companies which means you can actually reduce the compensation for them. Microsoft needs to pay the lower levels better just like other companies do.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for less than a year
pros: You get what you put in. If you want a good work life balance you can do that and be successful or if you want to put in a lot of extra hours you'll be recognized. Great pay and benefits.  Inclusive culture.  Easy to move around to other teams if you want to. My friends who were hired with me and didn't click with their first teams have mostly found new teams that they enjoy better.
cons: Some people are frustrated with the small scope of what they work on or the slow pace but I think that's just a symptom of the size and complexity of the projects you work on at Microsoft

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than a year
pros: Steady pay.  Location good.  Benefits good.
cons: Poor management.  No fringe benefits.
advice_management: Value your employees more.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Good vacation. Generous salaries. Some WFH ability (though this varies widely by manager)
cons: 60-hour weeks are the norms. Incompetent and Micro-managing supervisors abound. Sleeping your way to the top is not unheard of nor is the person in the senior position ever reprimanded.
advice_management: Why not weed out some of those dead wood directors who haven't upgraded their skills in years? Also if you want to have a serious working culture cut out the some of the "growth mindset" fluff that we must ignore whenever our supervisor says to ignore it.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Can be proud of a part of one of the biggest IT product
cons: Too much politic even within development organization

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Culture, free drinks and snacks, stretch assignments paid.
cons: Budget cuts with retail, management is vastly different by market, they preach work life balance but to no avail, workload is not comparable to pay.
advice_management: Reinvest in you people and culture as it continues to fade

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than a year
pros: Innovative again. Huge business opportunities in a very wide variety of business units. Shared goals across teams / orgs help to concentrate the efforts.
cons: A lot of old cons were taken care of. still a lot of opportunity to work on process simplification and work environment. single offices are not very up to date.
advice_management: Keep on doing! Explore new workplace environment strategies and communicate that with the employees. Let them decide with you how to work in the future.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft
pros: Flexible hours, work from home, friendly people, and there are a large number of opportunities to progress my career forwards.
cons: There are very few cons to working at Microsoft.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft
pros: Benefits, Work-Life Balance, Good School District around the Bellevue Redmond area. The city is also nice and is liberal, focuses on the environment
cons: Windows is the main cons I guess. Some managers are still stuck in the old culture which is definitely dying
advice_management: Embrace open source more. Get rid of Yammer, it is a piece of junk. Fix the internal search, why is it to terrible?

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
-Free Soda
- Healthcare isn't the worse in the industry 
- Pay is ok in the industry
cons:
- Satya has lost his mind and really thinks that IT is something that doesn't need to exist 
- Company is killing itself to make Azure work and it is failing
- IT Department cost tripled trying to move everything to Azure not including people  
- IT department is cutting vendor and FTE staff trying to do "more with less" calling dev/ops but with no real idea of what dev/ops means
- "Blue Box" means Product Groups doing their own IT without knowledge on how to do it
- Satya is making a mess of it.  Company will is seeing short term gains from dropping ops costs but will quickly start to stagnate and people start to choke on Azure.
advice_management: Get rid of the CEO.   The cloud isn't magic.  You need people to make it work.  Invest in innovation and don't shut it down because it isn't the "right" group to innovate.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros: Amazing benefits, Competitive pay, (Small) Bonuses, Free Surface tablet, Microsoft Office and other perks
cons: Horribly managed. Managers are allowed to hire friends and family which as you can guess is not a good thing. You are basically free to do whatever you want, whenever you want which may be considered a pro?
advice_management: Leave the company and go back to Walmart and best buy where you belong.

summary: "Amazing overall.  Too much time spent with internal meetings"
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Visionary management, Innovative products and services, Over-achieving employees, Amazing culture
cons: WAY too much time spent on internal meetings vs vital time with customers.  challenges with work-life balance.
advice_management: Reduce internal meeting time.  Otherwise keep on going!

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Good company, nice projects, smart people.
cons: Lots of work for a bit of progress.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time
pros: Really good benefits. Above average salary. And work-life balance can be achieved.
cons: Sometimes you get caught in the internal politics. Career growth can be stunted depending on whether you get a good manager.
advice_management: Watch for internal politics and middle layer management support for career growth.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Good benefits and great people to learn from.
cons: Corporate baggage and aggressively changing

summary: "Generally good, but employees are expendable, without hesitation, justification or compunction"
main_text: I worked at Microsoft
pros: Good salaries, and good benefits.
cons: With over 90,000 employees, you are just a number. Many of the jobs are being migrated to India, and other locations where salaries and other expenses are lower. Between constant reorganizations of management and assignments, it is difficult to build meaningful, constructive employee-manager rapport.
advice_management: Find a way to reduce the constant re-organizational churn.

job_title: Current Employee - Software Development Engineer II
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros: creative freedom, aggressive product releases, technology
cons: too big a company, growth is relatively solwer

summary: "Great place to work but falling behind other tech firms"
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great opportunity to grow your career, well respected employer, top notch benefits and good work-life balance. Company values and opportunity to give back to the community are really great
cons: Large company bureaucracy. Silly "Connect" performance review process (that supposedly isn't a performance review) that then leads to a pay raise based on "impact" which isn't defined in a way that aligns to the new values of the company. It is just weird.
advice_management: Other tech firms in the area are paying more. You may need to rethink your salary structures

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros: The culture and beliefs of the company make you feel good to work for someone who cares so much about its customers and employees
cons: None that I can think of, outside of the company not letting employees know where certain hardware divisions are headed ahead of time
advice_management: Work your way up, earning a management role will benefit you much more than being handed one

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros: good benefits, good office space, casual and fun atmosphere
cons: micro-managers abound here, corporate culture is set in Washington and doesn't always fit well for leading edge HW development

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros: great benefits and competitive salary
cons: Wish there were more locations for some jobs

job_title: Former Employee - Senior Software Design Engineer
main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Ample opportunities and challenging career. Many talented, professional software engineering teams involved to support world-class services.
cons:
Work/life balance is also ranked low in each year Work Health Index but management does not seem to take this serious, particularly for those working in the online cloud computing environment requiring 24x7.
Sometimes need to deal with legacy infrastructure before some improvements could be made to enhance systems.  A lot of overheads to perform some legacy tasks with less return on investment.  Slowly becoming to embrace open software standards but take lots of time to retrain workers with Windows knowledge.
advice_management: Review model, even though getting rid of the stack ranking, is essential the same as leads and managers must still need to provide a virtual ranking stack as a way to reward and evaluate individuals.  We were still losing good talents every year as the open source community has been able to attract more talents.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft  for less than a year
pros:
- Meaningful intern projects
- Great diversity of teams: Microsoft has their hands on absolutely everything, so you get to talk to a lot of very smart and interesting people.
- Probably has the best intern benefits out there. 
- Intern events are amazing.
- I've had great mentors
- It's a great time to join Microsoft in the midst of its reinvention
cons:
- The engineering mentality in some teams is not the best: software design is not given too much thought and lazy shortcuts, instead of an ideal solution, are often taken. This applies to teams that have a lot of legacy code.
- The internship experience depends a lot on the mentor. Most mentors are great, if you're one of the unlucky few, your internship won't be as rewarding.
advice_management: More thought to intern-mentor matching.

summary: "The best BigCo to work for in tech"
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft  for more than 5 years
pros: With the new applications being developed and acquired, Microsoft is at the top of their game.
cons: The only con is that it is truly a behemoth, the large nature of the organization offers less flexibility and less breadth of context.
advice_management: I wouldn't make any changes if I were making a recommendation to management.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft
pros: Great Place to work. !
cons: Nothing specifc to mention.
advice_management: the current process can be improved

main_text: I worked at Microsoft  for more than 3 years
pros: Great company for contract employment.  Worked there as a contract employee for nearly 18 years.
cons: It is a very big company and, as such, is very compartmentalized in how they go about doing business.  This creates a need for specialists more than general knowledge technologists.
advice_management: Diversify your positions

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft
pros: Great work life balance. Management invests in growth of employees. Place where you can really develop a career.
cons: Stock compensation has fallen relative to other large companies over the last few years.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than a year
pros:
The career development and opportunities are endless.
The culture is fantastic.  Everyone is so helpful and genuine achieving goals is easy.
The benefits are top notch.
Microsoft's total compensation is amazing.
There is a very strong emphasis on ethics which is really reflected in the culture.
cons:
I wish that formal training was more available.  
There are internal requirements to get certified on things, but getting approved for formal training isn't easy.
advice_management: Help us out with formal training classes where it makes sense.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros: Culture, People, Technology, Perks, Opportunities
cons: Salary, Microsoft specific technologies, Backward compatibility

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Opportunity to work with smart passionate people.
Good benefits including health insurance and stock options.
Competitive salary.
cons:
Your experiences will depend on the team and location in which you work.
Humility includes the ability to be open to new ideas and ways of doing things and many people who started their career at Microsoft and have never worked anywhere else lack this trait.
Some teams might be led by people who are not very collaborative and have political motivations.
advice_management: Foster a more open and collaborative environment across the company.

job_title: Former Employee - Senior Premier Field Engineer
main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Knowledgeable Peers, Lots of travel, Yearly team building events.
cons: Review structure lacking and constantly changing.  Management claims they promote work/life balance, but critique against peers who do not have any, so you are expected to perform the same.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft part-time
pros: Great Pay, a lot of innovation techniques
cons: Long hours and you have to work for it

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Agile, collaborative environment. The "one" microsoft way is refreshing and makes MS an entirely new company vs the Ballmer era.
cons: Still some holdouts trying to keep the old ways of internal competition rather than cooperation. Employees need to push the idea of cooperation.
advice_management: Need to see management pushing for the one Microsoft way as a priority. They need to forcibly stop the holdouts to either adapt or go elsewhere.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than a year
pros: Great benefits and work life balance, some truly exciting teams and projects to work on
cons: Some teams and projects are dragged down my management level politics. Need to watch out for those while joining.
advice_management: Be more transparent, still stuck in waterfall management model in organizations like Office

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: There are a lot of very bright people who are passionate about technology. In a short amount of time, the CEO has helped to restore the company's image as that of an innovator rather than a follower, and made needed changes to help MS become more competitive in the cloud game. Customers and partners alike are excited about Microsoft technology again and that is exciting to see.
cons:
In my opinion, morale is now pretty poor mainly due to the abundance of unnecessary admin/processes, internal politics and poor management. There have been more than a few layoffs (wrapped into "re-orgs") in recent years and the practice of stack ranking employees has continued, although mgmt attempted to obscure this by calling it something else (b/c of the negative press following the Vanity Fair article about 5yrs ago).  

For years now it seems that numbers have been set at unattainable levels so that most don't make their numbers. This started during the K.T. era (former COO), presumably to cut payout costs, but it has continued after his departure. If I recall, it started after the company announced an across the board raise in base salaries (apparently in response to 'employee feedback about too much compensation being tied to stock'). 

From that point growth targets seemed to get crazy and a lot of good people left. You'd have one good year but 2 bad ones. Mgmt might change quota or revenue recognition rules mid year and there's nothing you can do about it; or worse yet, you may not find out there was a rule change until the end of the fiscal when you're trying to figure out why your attainment number is off. Incentive plans are so complex that you need a PhD to comprehend. Reporting tools are often broken and you may not be able to accurately track progress against goal, so you may get screwed if you have a manager with few scruples or if you have a mgr looking for a sacrificial lamb for the bottom of the stack ranking.
advice_management: 1. Put in an end to the unrealistic numbers. You'll have a better shot at retaining top talent.  2. Provide a reporting system that works.  3. Reduce the number of re-orgs.  4. Truly bring an end to stack ranking. Don't just call it something else. Stack ranking doesn't breed better employees or even better quality work, it encourages politics and back stabbing which often prompts good people to leave.

summary: "A company that used to be Retail Heaven"
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
You learn a ton about technology, software and hardware.
Amazing benefits for a retail job.
Soft skills grow immensely.
Build great relationships with customers and co-workers.
cons:
Sales, sales and sales.
Constant micro-managing about everything!
Raise per year is based on performance (and even if you're doing really well, you don't get a lot more money)
Promise of promotion and career growth.
New employees are making more than employees with seniority.
Rude customers that degrade you.
advice_management: Micro-managing sucks. Stop focusing on only sales and promote real growth. When you hire new employees that make more than those of us that have been busting our chops the last few years -  we start to look elsewhere for employment.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft  for more than 10 years
pros: a lot of resource to learn and grow
cons: too much waste on non-productive things
advice_management: more focus on problem solving

main_text: I worked at Microsoft  for more than 10 years
pros: Your colleagues.  The breadth of technical investment and know how.  Satya, and the changes being made to be more customer obsessed and nimble.
cons: Middle management can be spotty.  Important to find the right team.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft  for more than 5 years
pros: Teammates and everyone I worked with on various projects were incredibly hard-working, professional, and positive. Even with project and scope changes -- which can be challenging -- we managed to adjust and support each other. I could always count on people to do what they say they are going to do.
cons: I worked in two areas while there. One of them was much better than the other. I won't name them, but you need to be careful when evaluating the team and manager. It is true that some overwork their employees without acknowledging the amount of work done, and have unrealistic expectations. My team was not like this, but the business group we developed training for had this issue. Very competitive as well.
advice_management: Give credit to employees and support them -- some do a great job at this and others try too hard to move up the ladder.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Good benefits, reasonable vacation, reasonably nice spaces,
cons: Cutthroat politics, old fashioned engineering practices, terrible build systems and source control
advice_management: Invest in tools that make engineers more efficient.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 8 years
pros: I've had some exceptional roles over the years; high innovation, exciting teams, big impact.
cons: Learning that delivering high value, impact, will not guarantee a good review, rewards, or career progression.  Too much hostile political maneuvering, especially as progress in levels.  I am one of those truly passionate geeks that loves what Msft has contributed to the world, and hope I have helped meaningfully over the years.  Unfortunately, can't stand the politics.
advice_management: Though most would not care even the slightest bit, need more managers to care about, and focus on, delivering real impact, rather than absolute focus on manipulating the system for personal benefit (including destroying careers and reputation of peers for personal benefit at rewards time).

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time
pros: Great learning and good pay
cons: Some space issues, politics, and budget issues for consultants

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros: Definitely a major change in culture since Satya came on as CEO
cons: Still dealing with the issues of a large scale business - politics, competition, duplication of effort across teams - but making big progress
advice_management: Keep up the good work

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros: So many successful and interesting product areas to work on, support to change roles internally for personally growth, strategic direction from leadership is really reinvigorating the company
cons: Big company can mean lots of process overhead and dispersed decision-making, leadership trying to streamline but still takes a long time to get things done

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than a year
pros: Lots of pride involved in working with Microsoft. For the most part, I felt like my team consisted of a bunch of talented, dedicated professionals.
cons: While Mr. Nadella states that stack reviews are no longer the norm, I can emphatically state that is not the case.  The practice is ongoing; 'someone had to be labeled the lowest performer' according to my former manager.  I was told that my manager's boss tried to get an exception to the mandatory personnel trim for our small group after I was labeled, and he was denied.
advice_management: I really believed that I was going to do great things in Microsoft. My first poor review came after a number of terrific 1:1 meetings with my supervisor, so I was blindsided by the horrible review. I immediately gave up my home life and worked massive hours, running laps around my peers in order to show my value and worth.  My teammates, my boss, and his boss all saw the improvement, but it didn't matter because there was a certain number of people who had to be eliminated.  I had a lot of ROI to bring to the business, and I'm sorry that didn't happen.  This personnel management style might work for a physical labor workforce, but it's arcane for a professional work force.  I wish I understood why there is a disconnect between Mr. Nadella's statement about stack reviews being eliminated vs my experience.  I still respect and admire him, but that is a huge disconnect, and it makes me wonder who is not telling the truth.  For a successful business to have to succumb to practices like this makes me shake my head in disbelief.  I expected better from Microsoft.

summary: "Big turn the crank company, good benefits, lacks innovation"
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Good benefits, middle of the road pay and bonuses, Awesome development tools
cons:
Every day is a fire drill.  You must spend large part of your time advertising how good you and your work are, rather than working to make products better.  Engineering seems to be more turn the crank than innovation.  Surface team spends a lot of time changing its mind and redoing rather than innovating.

Too much travel to China
advice_management: When you hire awesome people, stop over managing them.  Spend less time looking at the people that are trying to climb the ladder and focus on making awesome products.

summary: "Come for the $ if you don't mind politics"
main_text: I worked at Microsoft  for more than 10 years
pros:
- Great compensation package & benefits
- Smart people
- Hard problems
- Ability to work on products that are used by 1B people
cons:
1) Culture. Everyone is giving praise to the "New Microsoft." Satya can say all he wants that he's turning the place around and invests in people - but it's not entirely true. You have the same VPs running teams there and they continue to perpetuate favoritism and sexism. There is no safety at Microsoft. You may be okay in a role for a while, until there is a re-org. A new VP comes in and replaces all the leadership with people they know. That job you were waiting around for? Gone. It's given to someone the VP trusts.

Culture is also about how we treat each other. Office politics happen when there is a lack of trust in the workplace. Teams are still competing with the each other for resources. Within teams, managers are playing games to protect their own feature areas and resources. With respect to compensation, it gets worse. While MSFT can say they got rid of the stack rank, it's the same budget for rewards. It's not possible to give everyone a max payout with the budget. This means the VP takes from everyone to give top rewards to a few key performers.

2) If you ever join MSFT, good luck finding your next job. Many recruiters will question your ability to get anything done. There is definitely prejudice against MSFT employees in the valley.
advice_management:
- To really get rid of the stack rank, every team should be given an annual rewards budget which would allow VPs to grant a max payout for everyone.
- Clean house with your VPs. Time to bring in some outside blood.

summary: "Amazing company and wonderful opportunities, with some hiccups."
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Fantastic brand, it's an immediate conversation starter and attention grabber when people realize you work for Microsoft.  Also, there are phenomenal people that work in this company.  My peers and employees have enhanced my working relationship with Microsoft beyond words.  There are some amazing opportunities as well, if you ensure that you're the obvious choice and best fit for those opportunities.  Innovation and unique experiences are welcomed and appreciated in most orgs (though surprisingly frowned upon in others).  I've gained more substantial experience from Microsoft than any other organization I've worked for.  Though there are ups and downs as in any employee-employer relationship, I wouldn't trade the time I've worked at Microsoft for anything.  I feel more optimistic about my future outside of the company because of my accomplishments inside of the company.
cons: Culture, payrate, and benefits can vary from division to division for similar roles, and hard work is often unrewarded and trumped by politics.  To take advantage of some of the best opportunities, relocation (some paid, some unpaid) is often required and modifications to benefits/pay is the norm.  Also, the classic mentality of "bad managers" cause disengagement with the organization while great managers keep you motivated to perform at your best and inspired for what the future with Microsoft may hold is very much a part of working at Microsoft.  I've had some managers lie to me and peers and manipulate situations, while others have recognized me with bonuses and top company recognition.  Work life balance is also hit or miss depending on the org that you work in.  My experience is that as long as you sacrifice and overwork yourself to exceed expectations, you "earn" your "balance" in the work/life arena.  What may be expected from senior management at the top of the company in regards to the organization's values and expectations can be executed completely differently depending on the org and the managers that are above you.
advice_management: Need more consistency from manager to manager, and org to org.  Not personality or leadership styles, but big things like vision, purpose, and strategy execution.  Precedents and goals set by the CEO aren't always cascaded down properly, too many managers down the pipeline take liberties to spin their own agendas to enhance their careers or hit their goals or quotas.

summary: "Great place to work, very focused roles"
job_title: Former Employee - Senior Lead Program Manager
main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years
pros: I worked at MS for 7 great years. I learned a ton about how to build software, how to collaborate effetively, and how to manage a team. Some of my best friends came from my time working there, and there are so many really smart people there.
cons: After a while, the learning starts to be about how to succeed at Microsoft, rather than how to build software best. When I was there there was pretty limited customer interaction and data driven decision making, but I think that has changed somewhat since I left. In the end, the reason i left was so I could spend more time thinking about what the right thing to build for customers was, rather than figuring out how to build the thing I was told to build as well as possible.
advice_management: Continue to hire great managers that help develop. Continue to reward good performance and make people feel valued. Provide more customer connection, and more autonomy when it comes to what should actually be built to meet customer needs.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros:

Location

advice_management: Quit trying to be the worst of Amazon.

summary: "There are some good orgs and some not so good orgs"
main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
-Most people are passionate to create good products and good experiences for the customer
-Lots of different job opportunities.  There are hundreds of teams in Microsoft.  You can work on anything from games, to main stream products, to hardware, to research projects.  I had jobs in many different groups over my years there because I decided I wanted to try a new product.  Also, you can change disciplines.  I've seen many people want to change disciplines and they started getting experience in there current group and either took over the role in there current group or moved to a new group.
-The clique of there are lots of smart people there, and there are.
cons:
-Plans can change on an upper management whim.  There's no good reason other then someone way up the food chain had a pet idea they wanted in the product.
-Upper management expects everyone under them to provide schedules and such but they don't feel they should be held accountable to a schedule and we wait with no idea when the decisions that have major impact on our product will be made.
-Schedules get made that everyone knows can't be made but will only report that as the official schedule until it's blown.
advice_management: Set believable schedules, even if you don't like how long people feel it has to take.  And adjust them as soon as you know you can't make them.  Also, upper management, hold yourself accountable to believable schedules just like everyone under you is.  And I don't care how difficult the decisions are.  You get the big bucks to make those decisions.

Previous CEO made the decision which was left to the new CEO who clearly did not share the opinion of buying the Nokia handset business. This ended up ms not investing enough in the comeback and eventually ramping down the whole phone business and laying off 25k+ people. 
This is in a way evidence of ms going through big changes and if you happen to be in that side of the business which is not valued by CEO then changes and moves can be quick and they lay off people pretty fast.

Ballmer threw money at every problem and tried to buy any company he felt could get him out of the hole he dug. Nadella is doing everything he can to distance himself from the past mistakes and cutting everything. He's more accountant then an engineer.
