summary: "Great place to learn and grow, hard to drive change."
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 8 years
pros: One of the few software companies left that allows you to work in a small team but still have impact on a global scale.  Lots of really smart and motivated people.
cons:
- Culture change is happening but too slowly.  I still run into people everyday that exhibit "old" Microsoft thinking.  Culture change is uncomfortable and there are still too many comfortable people without the right incentive to change.  
- There are also too many people that weigh in on every decision.  Classic "too many cooks" dilemma.
- Bottoms up revolution does not succeed often and there are only so many Top Down initiatives that Management can drive.  As long as the metric for rewarding people is "business impact" (self delivered, helping others, building on others' help), it will always be possible to push aside everything else.
advice_management: Culture change needs "teeth" to overcome inertia.  Culture change is risky and Management is really good at managing risk.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
* Very competitive salary
* Nice benefits and perks
* You are very mobile in your career
* Relatively open to relocation
* Certain managers are very proactive about work/life balance
cons:
* Sometimes collaboration (especially with int'l teams) gets in the way of work
* Teams within the same division aren't always on the same page
* It's easy for people to get away with not doing their job and force you to pick up their slack
advice_management:
Be more communicative about work/life balance. Microsoft as a company is very understanding and proactive, but it's easy for individuals on a team to forget that.

Stop worrying about improving "culture" and "social perceptions" of Microsoft and start focusing on how to get consumers (especially Millenials) to understand that Microsoft is creating the best everyday tools and products out there.

job_title: Current Employee - Senior Director Product Marketing
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Large company with many exciting opportunities and job mobility. Well resourced with promising long term strategy. Compensation and benefits are generous.
cons: Negative culture at headquarters with over-functioning engineering team. Cross company initiatives are slowed by too many silos and approvals. "Growth hacking" is promoted in word but restrained by bureaucracy in action.
advice_management: Drive clearer swim lanes between engineering, marketing and sales. Enable cross-company initiatives instead of promoting territorialism. Promote positive and collaborative culture.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros: Challenging work and great work culture. People are helpful and provides full freedom for innovation and experiment new ideas.
cons: Compensation should be little bit less than talent competition. Due to this, a lot of talented people are leaving. Few of talent peoples are here - most of them are due to some constraints. Every one has feeling that we are less paid and tackling same challenging problems.
advice_management: Compensation should be raised. More innovation and hackathon practice at ground level. Remove as much manager as possible from company. We don't need PM in Microsoft.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Camaraderie is strong, the people I work with are amazing, I have made some life long friends. Opportunity to significantly grow my skills and add value to my team.
cons: Very poor communication across the company and to the partners causing confusion and complexity. Middle management tier is slow to adopt the "Growth Mindset", they are too focused on their careers rather than the company and their teams. Pay between men and women is still not equal, they get around that by using different job titles.
advice_management: Reward the people managers that have passion for people and are the catalyst for productive individuals. I cannot stress enough how important it is to have a manager that knows how to get the best out of every team member and tailored for each person. Stop loading them up with work their teams should be doing...let them lead and motivate!

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Smart people, flexible hours most of the time, good managers, good upside potential for career development and compensation bonsus
cons: Difficult to push software releases out due to company size and regulatory requirements, difficult to move within the company to different positions, position can be burningout
advice_management: All in all managers did a good job. Not sure I have additional input for management or managers at this time.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros: Working with great, smart people.  Get to work on cool tech.  A lot of independence - I've never had a micro-managing manager.  Collaborative environment.  Really good benefits.
cons: Benefits have been scaled back some over the last few years.  Job can be intense.  Not a place where you can coast - need to work hard to make it.  Some managers very metric-based
advice_management: Overall had a great experience with management but here's some feedback:  Don't manage based on just metrics.  Only implement processes when absolutely required.

Because of the size of the company there are diverse set of challenges and roles that you can take on and excel at. You get to work on products that impact millions of users.
cons: Because of the size of the company there are good managers and not so good managers, best way to deal with that is to vote with your feet. Because of the large scale of the products that you work on its difficult to measure the direct impact that you make.
advice_management: Keep the focus on customer value and innovations in machine learning.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than a year

cons: High stress, long work days, devops on-call rotations suck, saw abusive behavior by upper management to lower ranks,  lots of workaholics.
advice_management: Make day-to-day work life more humane.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft
pros: Microsoft is a solid reliable big company. A bad experience with one team doesn't mean you can't have a fabulous experience with another team within it. Its certainly a good company to learn your software craft, and also a great company if you are looking for a stable environment to work.
cons: Its a big company so if you're looking for edgy and hip its not the company for you (unless you want to learn your trade).

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time
pros: Having Microsoft on your resume may look great to certain future employers.
cons: They seem to be forced to remove a certain percentage of their team based on a curve, independent of how well everyone is doing.
advice_management: Don't wait until the end of the year to bring up issues.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Microsoft offers some of the best opportunities to learn in the industry. You'll learn more in the first month than you did in four years of college.
cons: It seems that Microsoft is always working through some sort of re-org (layoffs) so it can be difficult working in an environment where you are constantly worried about whether your job will be there tomorrow.
advice_management: Try to be a little less top-down and trust the lower level managers to run their business. They know what's going on better than anyone. Also, try to resist making major changes to parts of the business that you don't understand.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros: Microsoft is rediscovering its mojo under Satya. Focus has shifted to Being obsessed with customer, execution and singular pursuit of creating winning products
cons: There are still many many layers and multiple groupd trying to do the same feature making it difficult  to articulate the story
advice_management: Simplify everything -- fewer people, features, products, processes, org structures. Use less is more mantra. Establish clear accountability and hold people to it.

summary: "Just not what it used to be"
main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great people, smart people and overall a good environment to start a career.  While Microsoft isn't what it used to be, it still is a solid technology company.
cons: My reason for leaving was that the priority shifted over the years from creating great product for customers, to "who can stab you in the back quickest to rise in their careers".
advice_management: Be mindful of those that actually contribute at the 10x level.   You are losing those folks more and more and they are a different category of people in general.  Take care of them.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for less than a year
pros:
- Work/Life balance, Great Benefits, Flexible Work Hours
- Friendly environment, nice international culture
- Microsoft recently started accepting OpenSource and Linux as a reality. Windows 10 native support for Ubuntu Bash and Microsoft's contribution in github are examples of the new trend.
- Microsoft is serious about its cloud business.
- MSFT rewards loyalty; if you stay you will get promotion, bonus, etc.
cons:
- Microsoft's OpenSource culture is still an infant. A lot of company's time is wasted in reinventing the wheel due to the lack of a proper culture for reusing what already is available as a third party library. Hopefully this will get better over time but at slow pace.
- It is harder to make your contribution visible due to the nature of big companies.
- If you end up working in old product teams (e.g., Office) you may end up maintaining old code that you inherit and so you won't learn much new technologies.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros: Benefits, job flexibility, networking, atmosphere, technology advancements
cons: Work/life balance, advancement opportunities for the business support discipline

The resources available in such a large and diverse company.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 8 years

advice_management: Award collaboration. Make 360 degree feedback mandatory. And take it seriously when an employee has multiple HR complaints.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for less than a year
pros: Started working at Microsoft in July 2016, as my first full-time position after graduating college. So far it has been a great experience. They more or less completely covered relocation for me, which really helped me to move halfway across the country. The work has been good so far, definitely keeping me busy. In addition, the benefits and pay that Microsoft provides are top notch. All in all, very good experience so far.
cons: If you work in Redmond (I am in Bellevue, so this does not apply to me), I could see it being difficult getting to your building if you are not driving, as it is larger than the average college campus.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time
pros: I was paid very well, and worked with very intelligent people. Lots of initial effort provided towards training and cross-training as needs arise.
cons: Brutally target-driven culture, similar to some of the more vicious sales roles I've seen. Stack ranking is gone but the mindset is still prevalent. Engagement Managers would put Associates on projects they were unqualified for or were in the wrong subject matter area, just to achieve utilization targets.
advice_management: Get rid of aggressive targets, as it makes the place very hostile.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than a year

main_text: I worked at Microsoft

cons: Can't think of any, my time at Microsoft were the best days I have ever encountered
advice_management: Keep up the great work

summary: "Microsoft can be both a good and bad place to work"
job_title: Current Employee - Senior Software Development Engineer
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Treated well. People are generally good. Stock is doing well. Work life balance can be easily maintained. Compensation is fair.
cons: Depending on the organization within the company you work in, experiences can vary. I've had issues with how upper management approaches problems, our engineering systems, and the process it takes to get work done. Compensation doesn't feel as good as other big tech companies in the are.
advice_management: Listen to your customers better, it will make your employees happier.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros: Innovative, Open, New CEO, Good pay and technical colleagues
cons: Missed the tide in mobile space

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Salary, bonus, benefits, etc.  Being part of something big.  Good teams in several areas.  Smart people who want to do good work.
cons: Upper management out of touch with reality of the work. Middle management and up runs the company by scorecard only.  Virtually no first hand experience or street smarts to drive key decisions.  Company wants to get younger, cheaper. Trendy Amazon model of burn hot and burn out in 2 years.  Good for stock price, bad for employees.
advice_management: Step from behind the scorecard.  Do something real for once.  Meet a customer.  Write some copy.  Create a web site.  Anything that proves you know what you're talking about beyond company mantra du jour.  Stop the phony rah rah and use better common sense.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft
pros: The benefits are great and there are many opportunities for traveling abroad.
cons: It takes a long time to get promotions and there are too many layers of management. Many people's jobs are duplicative.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: A large company means you can get a lot of experience either in one particular discipline or in several. The sky's the limit for motivated individuals.
cons: The competitive nature of the review model. Though teamwork is valued, there's always an underlying pressure to do better than your peers. That's a disconnect.
advice_management: The usual things that top the employee poll every year -- communicate more effectively (transparency is key to a happy, motivated workforce) and keep working on tools/process improvement.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years

job_title: Current Employee - Principal Program Manager Lead
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Work on incredible technology with incredible people.  There is flexibility to change teams and work on ever changing areas.  The beauty of Microsoft is that if you are interested in Tech, it is likely being worked on somewhere at Microsoft.
cons: Work life can be very demanding and isn't recommended for people looking for an "easy job" - The program manager role requires skills beyond just technical acumen
advice_management: Continue to push for innovation and drive for business impact amongst product teams.  Be quicker to react to industry trends and cut ties with laggard or dying products or technology

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft  for less than a year
pros: I am completely in awe with some of the work I've seen going on in this company! The perks of culture here is rapidly migrating to adopt many of the garage mentality of doing epic "stuff" and being a doer. I've been in meetings where I am easily the dumbest dev in the room (this is a good thing). It's very personally rewarding being challenged with the scale of products used by millions.
cons: The "sexy" products are fiercely competitive. Much of the time in meetings is a waste and there is a huge duplication of effort between various teams.
advice_management: It would be helpful to have some form of "all up" Kanban or similar to know when teams are doing incredibly similar projects. Also, please stop killing off hardware products (phones, band) just as they are gaining momentum. It damages credibility within the company and with our users.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time

advice_management: I like the push towards a new Microsoft, the culture is great, but some of the old Microsoft tendencies are still there. Let's push to be as less on process as possible - some if it feels like a waste of everyone's time. Also, our base salaries are competitive in the industry, but I don't think the stock and bonuses are.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft  for more than 10 years
pros:
Senior Leadership Painting refreshing new vision and strategy

advice_management:
EPG needs massive rebuild. 
Place focus on customer and not managing ones own career each day
Have courage
Reward courageous thinkers
Work out yesMen/Women - Way too many of these. 
Break out teh Dynamics business so they can be more Agile and Strategic

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years

summary: "Great benefits, flexible, but a big company feel"
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
* Great benefits and facilities

* Really big company, easy to feel lost in the crowd
* If you've enjoyed working at startups or small companies, you won't get that here

job_title: Former Employee - Software Development Engineer II
main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Generally smart people, good benefits, good work life balance. Good fitness reimbursement program, very good 401k match program. Very good library system. Good commute program (connector)
cons: No free food. Rainy days can be quite a lot during winter time. Also culture can be quite different from team to team.
advice_management: Provide free food and boost pay, then you'll likely to get and keep good people.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Good pay, good benefits.  Semi-casual dress code.  Huge company with tons of opportunities, around the world.  Great support for very ambitious people.  Plenty of chances to get management experience.  New leadership team is making necessary changes - but those changes might not work out for you...
cons: A monoculture - if there is a sense that you might be a Republican, you will likely get managed out.  If you like your job and just want to keep doing it, you will get managed out.  If you are a white male and they find a minority or female candidate, you will likely be fired in order to make the quota.  They don't hide this fact - quotas are published, headcount is shrinking - the only way the math works is to force out white males.  If you take advantage of the great vacation/leave benefits, you will get a terrible review.  Whatever you do, if you are a male - DO NOT TAKE YOUR 12 WEEKS PARENTAL LEAVE!!!
advice_management: Upper management is making the right moves, for the most part.  Think about reducing the number of managers and increasing scope.  There are way too many layers.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Good benefits.  Ok vacation policy.  Lots of products to potentially work on.  A couple years ago, you had to be in a position for 18 months prior to interviewing for another position (or get managers approval).  That's no longer the case.

Satya and Brad are great.
cons:
New Review process is very much the same as the old one.  Your manager can make or break your career and there are, quite frankly, many people in management that shouldn't be there.  

Nepotism, favoritism and bias are all present (as with many large companies).  When they are ready for you to go, they will nitpick to no end.  The things that you're penalized for would, in some cases, get others promoted.  Microsoft really seems to love the boisterous.  If you're a worker bee or introvert, this may not be the place for you.  The loud person who's always talking and making promises, yet saying nothing and hardly ever delivering on the promises, are the ones who are favored, rewarded and promoted.

If you ever get a review where you receive no rewards (no bonus, stock or raise), your career at Microsoft is virtually over.  Start looking elsewhere.
advice_management: The so-called non-stack ranking system sucks.  You still have inefficient and non-empathetic managers in place.  The so-called Diversity & Inclusion programs are mostly useless.  You may have some (and it's small) diversity, but the inclusion part?  Not even close.  Also, you get people in the door but do little to grow their careers and help them stay.

summary: "Good company that is doing things better and better each day and treats their employees well."
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Pays well, most teams are not really that stressful, respectful teammates, products are well known, development process goes through enough rings to ensure stability when features get to customers.
cons: Boring weeks, extremely slow processes, the company is always the last to enter the competition. The Redmond campus is in the middle of nowhere.
advice_management: Be a bit more agressive when entering a new area to compete. For example, the Mobile OS is sensational, but the company has not cared enough for mobile devices.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft
pros: Great company, amazing pay. I really love the company's values, which is why I chose to work there. I was happy to see the values being upheld even as an employee. Employees are awesome.
cons: The work can sometimes be demanding. It is not really demanding in the sense that it consumes your personal life, but more so in that it can be really tedious. This is not much of a con if you already expect it.
advice_management: The company is on the right track. To change anything substantiative may change the entire dynamic of the company. Continue maintaining the company's reputation and treating employees with respect and it will remain one of the top companies.

summary: "Software Engineer Review Working in SQL Server Team"
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years

1. Learning new technologies, Cloud, Web, Data Science etc.
2. Opportunity to work with teams working on innovative products and complex problem.

Too much focused in technologies specific to Microsoft only, though things are changing and there are lots of good open source projects.
Work life balance is not good any more. However, hard work is well rewarded in Microsoft.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than a year
pros:
Bonuses are larger, especially once you've been there for more than 5 years and have a large stock pile of stock vesting (twice) each year.
Most managers allow you to have a flexible work schedule.
cons:
Releases are rushed, which leads to (usually 1-3) months where you are working nights and weekends to get a feature developed before the code complete deadline. Then the feature still doesn't ship for another 6-9 months after.
Getting stuff done is slow.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years

job_title: Current Employee - Principal Group Program Manager
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Some of the greatest productivity software in the world, with a evolving philosophy in line with the 21st century
cons: While leadership has changed for the better, the layers right below it still.comprise of old timers that have made their fortune in the "Windows first" era - depending the area you work on, this can stifle innovation.

summary: "Great company if you land a good team"
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for less than a year
pros: The variety of teams available in the same campus really makes Microsoft into a goldmine of opportunities. Landing on a good team can make going to work feel like just hanging out. Work/life balance is excellent compared to other companies trying to make the office a 2nd home.

advice_management: Every team NEEDS to move to agile and email needs to be killed.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft

cons: Extremely competitive.  In some cases the same work would be given to more than one person to see who would do it best.
advice_management: There must be a better way to recirculate high performers throughout the company after a job has been completed.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft
pros: Microsoft has the best life-work relationship because it provides quality while working and balances it with flexible schedules. Top profiles and a lot of access to information and resources makes you want to learn faster and do more to also achieve and deliver more.
cons: The company's structure is so big that it sometimes it takes a long time to actually develop or achieve something.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft  for less than a year
pros: very challenging working environment, great benefits, work life balance and fair reward system
cons: some people still influenced by the old managerial style

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Excellent benefits, smart leadership, strong embrace of diversity and inclusion, philanthropy. Some of the smartest people I know work at Microsoft.
cons: As with most very large corporations, Microsoft can be slow moving and bureaucratic. It is critical to get to know people across groups and build your network.
advice_management: Keep up the good work and continue to focus on ensuring that selection of people managers are the most critical factor to retaining talent.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Lots of opportunities to change your job and career without changing your commute or your 401k!  As in any large company, each division and large group has some of the personality of the people that are attracted to that line of work.  Find a good spot and dig in.
cons: a big company needs to be agile with the industry, and that means that the start and stop businesses.  You need to be flexible, because there may be a change in your group and you might need to find another job within the company if you stay at the company a long time.
advice_management: Benefits and culture are easy to overlook when you are always focused on product and business success, but they make a big impact in how productive people are.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft  for more than 3 years
pros: Great to work with technical folks and architect.  Kitchen is well stocked.
cons: No available permanent office.  Office supply is not stocked well.
advice_management: Provide assignment quickly for your staff.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for less than a year
pros: Microsoft is a great large company to work for right out of college. Great benefits, great work-life balance (depending on your product team), and great pay. I'm learning a lot, but I think that's because I'm young and there's a lot to learn at my age.
cons:
It's a big company. Operations and procedures are slow. Communication within the company is hard, especially for remote offices (not in Redmond, WA). I don't feel passionate about my product (Enterprise & Cloud) but it's definitely an interesting and money-generating space. 

The stack rank/hierarchy is annoying. People will automatically default to the wishes of their manager, without thinking of the product's potential. 

I can't see myself here for more than a few years, but I feel I'll learn a lot while I'm here.
advice_management: Allow your worker bees to disagree with you every once in a while. Stay technical and don't become irrelevant in a rapidly changing industry. At the same time, know that everyone is human and imperfect.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Smart people to work with, opportunity to have global impact, amazing breadth of products and services means many different types of teams to work on
cons: Very rare to find a good people manager.  Rewards calibration system is a stack-ranking exercise and even very talented people with good results lose out if their manager doesn't champion them sufficiently.
advice_management: Managers use the rewards discussion process to "RIF" team members without notice and no severance pay.  So people who have never been told there is a performance issue are effectively fired.  This practice doesn't map to Microsoft company values and should be examined and ended.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than a year
pros: Great pay and benefits, extradinary coworkers, brilliant and team oriented.
cons: Worklife balance.  Also require folks to sell every product vs. becoming a specialist for our focus product.  Complicated Licensing.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros: Drive group of people to work with. So many opportunities for advancement. Great work hours.
cons: Management team overlooks the amount of work they assign.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft
pros: Nice location in Redmond, good teamwork, good project managers, and finally good ping pong lobbies.
cons: They hire and fire regularly. It's hard to find a safe job unless you're a higher up.
advice_management: Stop hiring and firing so regularly, although I do concede your firing benefits are good.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time
pros: Microsoft has a strong consumer and business brand. Alignment on key business outcome is clear and has many smart people working there.
cons: Internal processes and metric organizational structure can take up a lot of time to manage and therefore less time focusing on the customers.
advice_management: N/A

summary: "Building a future for each of us"
main_text: I worked at Microsoft
pros:
* good pay
* good benefits
* generally working with people who want to make a difference
* open to hearing differing opinions
cons: * depending on where in the company, speed of decision making and execution can feel very slow
advice_management: It is okay to show vulnerability, but clearly show vision and how it is translated to decisions in the mid AND low areas in the organization.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time
pros: Strong benefits including healthcare, stock and employee discounts.
cons: Inauthentic leadership that are focused on their own success and not building and supporting strong teams.  A lot of lip service is paid to attitude and collaboration but in reality the culture is highly political and divisive.
advice_management: Pick and choose the important Key Performance indicators that should be prioritized.  16 is too many for anyone to focus on and successfully deliver.

job_title: Current Employee - Senior Technical Account Manager
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Lots to learn. cutting edge. fast pace.
cons: many different groups competing against each other.  low level management overhead no value
advice_management: reduce process and tools that get in the way of customer value

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
- Excellent benefits
- Good compensation
- Some of the engineers are very brilliant, and you can learn a lot from them
- Friendly atmosphere
- Work-life balance can be however you want
- Microsoft gives devs very good hardware and an above average working environment
cons:
- Hiring quality is not uniform. Not all hires are of excellent quality
- Management is still somewhat risk-averse
- Engineering practices and agility seems lower than our competitors, specifically Amazon and Google.Though there has been a recent push for quality over merely shipping new features quickly
- Certain products such as Windows Phone leave die-hard Microsoft fans (our most important customers) disappointed. We should make sure we don't deliver half-assed me-too products into the market
advice_management: Keep doing what you are doing, drive the company to both improve quality and to push new features that make Microsoft products stand out

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great benefits package, even with the change to the HSA and the high-deductible plan. Great working environment and usually your own office (once you have sufficient time at the company). Each group or manager is different but the options to move around the company are great. You can definitely find something to work on that you are passionate about.
cons: Wtih the elimination of the test discipline at Microsoft, I think they've lost something special. Test people are the customer advocate and when everyone is a developer, there can be a tendency to focus just on shipping as fast as possible. and leaving quality secondary.

summary: ""That idea you have that Microsoft runs well, is a total myth" - Bing Manager Day 1"
job_title: Current Employee - Paid Search Account Manager

Pay is typically higher than the market

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: The company has a great brand and there is good mobility within the company which can offer some folks good mobility.  If your skills fall within a particular narrow range, they will keep you busy using them.  Mostly software consulting
cons: The position of Enterprise Strategy Consultant is supposed to be an Enterprise Architect role, but the sales staff in nearly every market has no visibility at all to senior business leaders, making it nearly impossible for Microsoft to get people engaged in doing Enterprise Architecture work.  If you are a TECHNICAL architect, you'll do fine in MCS but if you are actually an Enterprise Architect or Business Architect, Microsoft Consulting Services will NOT be a good place to work.
advice_management: End the pretense.  Either back the notion of architecture driven sales and build a sales team capable of selling Enterprise Architects, or close the Enterprise Strategic Consulting program down.  You do the brand no favors by going half way.

summary: "Good company, lots of diverse positions and cultures"

cons: Cultures can vary greatly from one team to the next. Make sure you like the team's culture when you decide to join

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Great Employer that really looks out for it's employees. Access to everything you need on Campus.  Great people in lead roles that take the time to listen to the people working with them.
cons: As I left we had transitioned to strange team structure that made it difficult to figure out what you would be working on in the next product cycle.  Location in Redmond is great for people with families, but not so much if you happen to be younger and single.
advice_management: I understand the appeal of the looser management system allowing people greater flexibility in what they work on, but unless the chaos it causes is balanced out, the quality of the product will suffer in the long run.  Please continue with weekly one on one meetings with leads, as it really helps employees understand the bigger picture.

job_title: Current Employee - MSIT - Senior Program Manager
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
* ability to learn new things, and move around the company if desired.
* many experts in all fields, so opportunity for those who are aggressive and go after it.
* pay is fair, but not the highest against competators right now.
* if you try and are luck to align with a good manager, you can have work/life balance.  Its dependant on the Manager and GM you report to more than anything else.
* Healthcare coverage for my family is good with Premera Blue Cross.
cons:
* Annual payroll amount for Healthcare went from $0 to $5K in recent years, no one remembers or even considers this a problem.  Thanks Obamacare!  And my wife's doctor and my doctor have retired in the past year in their own words because of the mess in healthcare regulations.
* Stack Ranking went from Overt to Covert in my organization.  Employees spend most of their capital to get 'recognized' for their own work vs. working with others to have all of us succeed.  
* Therefore, it's changed back to being 'too competitive' to be enjoyable any longer.
* way, way too many india vendors and employees have come in thru the visa programs.  We are flooded with HCL and other large vendor companies bring more and more india vendors onboard, and I approve and fill out all these documents to support it.  Still struggle after the past 5+ years of this model, to get even 1/2 the productivity and value from a co-worker or vendor than all the peers that were laid off in this time and are still struggling to work out there.  
* I know many that it were laid off that it broke their spirit and confidence soo much.  Still sad.
* Managing healthcare bills is so much more complex and time consuming that several years ago when Premera did this.  It takes much more work time away from the job to tack and re-submit and deal with these items.  Again, nobody is listening as I always submit the feedback and they only say 'this is the new normal'....and some other excuse.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time

advice_management: There is no point in offering advice, it will either not be considered or not comprehended, one of the two.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time
pros: Casual dress. Laid back environment freedom to move around office. Work stations was designed and classy. Management was laid back overall.
cons: Not enough personnel on weekends and holidays. Always shifting their responsibilities on others. Negative attitudes, not approachable, or helpful. They tend to hire more inexperience employees than experienced. So the turnover rate is extremely. Lack of communication or relationship building from Human Resource Dept. No kind of Grace with tardies or absenteeism. No support or concern.
advice_management: KEEP adequate staffing for customers as well as controlling overtime margins. Their should be open door policies at All times. Proper training strong relationships within the team. Equal treatment among employees as well as management. Supervisors should follow their proper schedule  and their accurate account of vacations. Lead by example.safety training, meetings according to Osha Standards. A safety walk should be done first priority at beginning of each shift. As well as periodically the whole shift. Proper PPE, worn at times, in Good conditions. Shipping trucks check according to the check list. Also ALL trucks tarp for bad weather coming in or going out. All off site vehicles should checked.

summary: "Overall a very good place to work"
main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Very smart people, most of them generous with time & knowledge. Huge company with many locations, teams and opportunities. Reimburse tuition if you pursue an advanced degree after hours. If you are focused and want to learn & grow, it's a great place to work.
cons: Lots of reorganizations and lots of management turnover. This can slow your progress toward promotions and create ambiguity around team goals. It can also tamp down perceived results at review time. On a separate note, as across tech in general, work pressure has stepped up in the last couple years or so.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft

advice_management: change back to old stack ranking system, it was better

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than a year
pros: My current favorite thing about Microsoft is my manager - he is super supportive and allows a lot of room for flexibility and creativity in my career. Other favorites include our beliefs for giving to those in need, working with super smart and talented and passionate people, and the pay/benefits are not too shabby.
cons: It's a really big company and so building a network inside the company to move your career in the direction you want it to go is important. This is not necessarily a con, but it does mean that you have to work harder to grow.

summary: "Politics is real, but so is impact"
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft  for more than a year
pros:
All sorts of technical and people challenges to work with.
Great benefits.
cons: Team dynamics and people challenges make it harder to do your best.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros: Turning around under Satya's leadership.  Big focus on Diversity and Inclusion although still much to be done.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
There are good people there. 
Made lots of friends and connections. 
A wealth of technologies and roles can be yours!
Depending on the group: a good work-life balance.
The company itself appears to be on a good trajectory!
cons:
This may sound like "sour grapes" due to recently being laid off by them, but here goes. (Note, most of this has to do with the last group I was in. I hope many others find this NOT to be true.)

* No loyalty: After 10+ years, I came in one day and was let go with FIVE days to find a new job internally. HR doesn't even move that fast! It wasn't performance-based (it came as a surprise to my manager, too) and via the black box that is HR I can only speculate why I was let go: politics? ageism? racism? I was too short? randomly? etc...

* Management in some orgs view devs as indistinct work units. "For project X I need Y people." Talent, experience, etc. doesn't matter as much anymore; just someone with a pulse that's breathing and knows C#.

* Politics. Sure, most places have it, but my last position was the first time I've seen retributive actions taken by senior management to get rid of less-than-supportive team members (not me).

* Cronyism: I've seen my teammates not get funding for plane travel from his hometown to campus (Redmond) once every 3-6 months and thus traveled via bus. Meanwhile friends of senior management fly home weekly to California. Friends and the "good ol' boys" are more important than the business or fairness. Even while I was getting laid off, certain "good ol' boys" were still hiring their friends from outside Microsoft.

* Sexism: Our group's leadership were entirely comprised of Indian males. Unfortunately India has a prevalent sexist culture in many places, and this was transferred to our group. I have Indian friends (male and female) who agree with me, so please don't accuse me of being racist. The women in our group were frequently marginalized and one quit after being told to "shut up and be quiet" during a meeting. Not wishing to cause waves none of them wanted the bother and hassle of reporting it to HR so they just left.

* Lack of support for remote folks. It's the 21st Century and some entire orgs have a "no remote" policy.
advice_management:
Please protect women. Give them a safe (anonymous?) space to report things. The ones I spoke to knew that our HR contact was good friends with our senior management and complaints (of which there were some) went nowhere.

The internet is wonderful and allows people to connect from all around the world. Let them work there too.

summary: "Great place to work, not so great to grow a career"
main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: You can learn a lot about shipping products in a global scale, and be exposed to all the different disciplines required to do so. If your project is the shiny new thing, you can get virtually unlimited resources.
cons: You get rewarded for what you can bring to the table today, not for your growth potential. And if your project is not a shiny new thing or not a big source of revenue, expect it to be cut very soon.
advice_management: Reinvest in quality testing before shipping products to customers, and invest in growing the people you already have in the company.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft
pros: Lots of opportunities are available. Great work/life balance.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than a year
pros:
The diamonds in the rough: some people there were truly good, intelligent, helpful human beings.
Resources to find out what you need.
Global recognition
cons:
Directors who are more concerned with solidifying their position in the company than mentoring, helping, supporting their direct reports.

Combative vs. collaborative mindset.

Corporate marketing dictates to the world (local markets) too much not allowing those in the field to do what needs to be done.

To much covering your butt instead of concentrating on customer value, customer wins, customer loyalty.
advice_management: Shake up the culture, become customer focused and cycle out the lifers. Politics doesn't equate to skill.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great benefits and pay.  Health care is very good.  Well known brand globally.
cons:
Middle Management and Organizational complacency abound.

Vision for company changes almost quarterly.  Big bets like Nokia & Skype get scrapped or changed so much that the business units end up failing all together.
advice_management: Stick to a long term plan.  Get rid of at least two layers of middle managers/directors and have more people working rather than pushing powerpoint presentations.

There are very few companies with projects at this scale.

cons:
Politics. Politics. Politics.  Every team is trying to do the right thing for the company, but would step on every other team to advance their goals.
Redmond.  It's an awful commute from Seattle proper.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 8 years

cons:
-Lack of Focus
-No strategy, still flying blind in many areas
-Company has been preaching data driven decision making but this is still a company that uses top down decision making, without much respect for data
advice_management: Don't just preach diversity but act upon it. Diversity is not just about having women or minorities at work, it is about company that is open to different view points, different styles of working. Microsoft continues to be company that rewards folks who can be loud, over the top vs. thoughtful thinkers

job_title: Former Employee - Senior Product Marketing Manager
main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Benefits remain strong, decent salaries, company is headed in right direction now that Satya Nadella is at the helm.   If your boss or group can sidestep the crushing demands of the MSFT machine and focus on doing great things for the customer, there is no better place.
cons: Way too bureaucratic and overly matrixed.  Too much shared ownership results in no one owning anything.  So much internal focus on providing reports to upper management that compromises customer interaction and execution.
advice_management: eliminate the layers and overly bureaucratic processes that keep your employees inwardly focused.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time

advice_management: Stop reorging and communicate a more concrete business plan or direction

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: While Microsoft is a big employer and has some of the impersonal flaws that come with lage corproate environments, they really do take care of their employees. The benifits are excellent in terms of healthcare, ESPP, 401K matching, bonuses, and stock.
cons: Advancement can be slow and the level system is designed more to control cost than develop employees.
advice_management: Set peple free. Show them they don't have to leave the company to make a big move.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Most employers are holding people into an area of expertise and limit their growth.  On the contrary, Microsoft encourages self-driven challenges to the culture and career path.  It is an excellent company to work for.
cons: As with any large company, it can be difficult to gain visibility for the great work that is happening in a group or individually. Cross company collaboration can also suffer.
advice_management: Embrace chaos and build a creative culture in every opportunity.  Look for diversity among teams and move people around to encourage new experiences.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: There are so many opportunities to learn, fine tune your skills, and seek out new experiences.  You really can do almost any job that exists on the planet.
cons: You definitely need to own your career and actively manage your network in order to move up and around the business.  If you are not careful, you can get "typecast" in a particular role and function.  Keep updating your skills, keep learning, and don't stay in one place too long.
advice_management: Do a better job of organizing for effectiveness and role clarity.  There is so much duplication of work across the business that detract from our ability to invest and innovate.  The reorganization gene runs strong @ Microsoft and we aren't efficient at it yet.  We need to reduce reorganizations and when we do them we need to execute more effectively.  We lose too many good people due to the churn caused during reorganizations.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time

advice_management: Management can do a better job of letting the employees know where they stand. Also, provide more assistance to employees when they are seeking advancement.

..only management who is so carried away with trying to do the right thing.
The only question is who are we doing the right thing for?
advice_management:
Leadership under Satya is great. The ideas are coming in, you can sense a wave of change. 
However, it is not enough when leadership engulfs on a mission like this.. you need everyone to play along. Unfortunately, that is not always happening.  And if you make things visible, you will be slowly bur surely be either forced out of the team or the company. People should never be afraid of doing the right thing and should also never be afraid to make mistakes.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros:
working with very talented people.
nice benefits (health care, stock options)
flexible time/ability to work from home.
cons:
stressful environment.
employees on all levels feel insecure about their job.
working between 50 to 85 hours a week.
work/life balance almost non-existent....up to 25% travel and late night calls with overseas are the norm.
Numerous daily/weekly scorecards and status reports to upper management are common ....data manipulation and wishful thinking is an accepted practice while preparing the reports.  
Burnt-out senior employees are replaced with fresh college graduates (college graduates are sent for month long business travel at a time).
Alcohol consumption during business hours and group meetings is an accepted practice (this can be a Pro for some).
Annual employee evaluations are based on stacked ranking (the evaluation is not called by this name) which results in noticeable employee turn over and caustic culture within and among groups.
advice_management: Address the items in Cons section.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft part-time for more than a year
pros: Benifits, free phone, tablet, there was nothing good about this place outside of the free stuff.
cons:
Managers are just rediculous.
And staff is two faced. They tell you to go to them if you need help, when they secretly report to managers about anything and everything you do. Do not trust anyone here.

Asinine writeups for things they do countless times, such as a manager daily would drop the F bomb multiple times a day and say other bad words as well, when we get written up for an accidental slip up swear.

Manager asked me if she wasn't putting out after I had a conversation with my female friend. If I said this about their husband or wife, I'd be fired instantly. 

Manager would constantly harass me for asking questions when first starting employment, then get angry that I asked questions, just wanted to make sure I did my job correct. (I have aspergers) 

When I confronted the manager who harassed me I was told I'm not thinking growth mindset and It's my job.... it's my job to be harassed because I asked questions? Terrible.

I have two jobs. Working 6 am and Microsoft all the way till 10 pm. They would hold me later at night because they wouldn't have their stuff together and would make people go on overtime when they aren't even suppose to. Very unorganized. So I get 5 hours of sleep because they fail at their jobs? 

Manager also would complain I wasn't following the steps of service... which I did by the book, got a 10/10 review as well as a full attachment item. And they still complain, never would they try and give positive feedback.

When I asked about the feedback problem why they are always negative, they say I can't take constructive criticism. It's always negative, even if you do things right. 

Over 70% of the employees there hate it, and are only there because of the company benifits. Most are looking for a new job.

Manager would make non racial problems into racial problems because of insecurities. 

I was discriminated agaisnt, and even told them of my aspergers before applying to the job. 

One thing that really blows my mind.. they tell you to enforce a no chair policy when sitting near xbox section. When I enforced this policy, the customer was unhappy about it and I was written up for "talking bad against the customer" When I never said any word to him. All I did was ask a manager if they needed to be moved to confirm what they told me before. 

This place is a joke, the turnover and employees is a joke, they leave and get fired because this place is run by jokes. Retail management wad the worst here than any other place I worked for.
advice_management:
Don't be hypocritical, and follow by example. When you all cuss, and act innapropriate in front of your employees, they get the wrong idea of how you should act in a work place. 
Grow up.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Microsoft gives one the opportunity to work with brilliant people and has many diverse areas to create new technologies used by millions around the world.

advice_management: Things are getting better under Satya, but there's still too much silo'ing and organizational hierarchy. Flatten the orgs, empower the feature crews, and reward results, not just the shipping of software.

job_title: Current Employee - Principal Group Program Manager

job_title: Former Employee - Senior Software Development Engineer
main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
My career was spent entirely within the Office organization so all comments here reflect that experience:
* Opportunity to work with a vast array of technologies and types of development (mobile, desktop, enterprise, services)
* Decent salary with great benefits
* Company is stable with tons of resources to take big risks
* Flexible work schedule
cons:
My career was spent entirely within the Office organization so all comments here reflect that experience:
* Depending on work from a partner team can be risky, especially if the partner team is in a different division. For example, if the other division has a substantial re-org, the work you were counting on may no longer be a priority.
* Performance assessment sometimes reduces to a nebulous "level of impact and influence"
* Shipped products will be deprecated or changed to something incompatible without a good path to an alternative. This is especially problematic for customers but can be demoralizing for employees as well.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft
pros: Stable, long-term financially profitable company
cons: Disregard for employees and customers. Concerned only with the bottom line.
advice_management: Go back to your roots, when Bill was at the helm, when the product, the technology, and the customer was the priority, and the employee was a family member, not a cog and a commodity.

summary: "Good place, lot's depends on your business group"
main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time
pros: Good salaries and benefits that changed quite often. Lots of time PTO available and structure around everything making it simple and easy to use.
cons: It's a huge company. It's inevitable that sometimes you feel like a number, but overall this didn't happen to often.  Different business groups have vastly different cultures.
advice_management: Working more and Director and Manager level transparency to their employees.  Directors need to take more accountability for decisions they may say in meetings that aren't documented.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft  for less than a year

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Overall good benefits and opportunities in general for all emploees
cons: Terrible review model though they say company has moved on from it but if you received a bad review even as a result of bad management situation your review retains on the HR system any time you apply for a new open positions. HR creates a road block for the hiring manager to get Leadership approval even though they claim Microsoft is an equal opportunity employer.
advice_management: Abolish old review model and the leadership approval practice and give a fair chance to all previous employees atleast for a interview to prove they have skills and experience. Accept there are possibilities person may be genuinely stuck in bad situation and not necessarily bad performer.

They have snacks 24/7 that everyone freely takes advantage of to feed their family at home. Hell, why no t take the whole family to dinner for free? It's all good, because employees take advantage of free lunch right ?
cons: If you are not a direct employee, it is modern slavery in mountain view ca. The characterization group is no product people. They have not idea of the design process or even know what they want in the first place . This is a kinder garden science fair where they think bullying works to strike innovation from seasoned product people. Is disrespecting people a real culture you want mr CEO???
advice_management: Purge the characterization group. Project management is not effective, a pretender by bullying and lying to his personal end, not for Microsoft embraced culture. Middle management are corrupt and incapable of making good decisions due to overt political atmosphere ? Why do superiors have to shout at meetings ? Is that how they do things in India ?

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time

main_text: I worked at Microsoft  for more than a year
pros:
I love the people I work beside. They are my family
Great people attract great people
I love having the freedom to experiment and fail, and still support my actions
We have been asked for an opinion on a regular basis, and we are allowed to speak our mind without fear
I love being a part of something larger that makes a difference. I love that everyone cares and that you have flexibility when needed
I love the variety. Every day is different and I get to interact with such a varied groups/people. It means I am always learning
I love that my job challenges me every day in different ways
The people at this company are a pleasure to work with and make it enjoyable to come to work
We all work hard and are recognized for doing so
My co-workers and management team are social, knowledgeable and caring
I am learning all the time, from the best people
I have the freedom to think outside the box and have all thoughts considered
I am allowed to grow and show my potential
I am able to use my skills and knowledge as well as push myself in areas that I am unsure of myself
I'm paid well, and I just love the job I do
cons: I had a manager who micro managed. They are the worst kind because they hire someone who can do their job well yet don’t let them do it. They will also try and take the credit if the person they hired has done something great for the company. They usually have fear another person is out there ready to take their job. They usually get close to one or two people and those people are her/his spy. These kinds of managers will add stress to your life and make the whole workplace pitted against one another ( the old united we stand divided we fall ) . They like it when employees don’t get along because that gives them more control. I quit a job because of an idiot manager like this. Many told HR what she was doing but HR dropped the ball and never did anything about it and that is why there was always a high turnover there.
advice_management:
First and foremost, keep an eye on how many of your people leave. Even if your company doesn’t do 360-reviews, and your own boss doesn’t have a beef with your management style, a mass exodus is a bad sign. 
Good managers know that their job is to look out for their employees’ interests, as well as those of the company. They also don’t expect (or want) to be best friends with their reports.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Compensation and perks are generous and work-life balance is very good. People typically show up and leave as they wish assuming they get the work done.
cons: Not a lot of career growth for employees at the company. There is no grooming or succession plans for new management, and oftentimes colleagues are pitted against each other to interview for their old manager's boss ... just to have an external candidate get the job.
advice_management: There needs to be managers who invest in their employees and more than just compensation and perks, but more about talking through a roadmap of how to succeed and move up in the company.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years

cons: District management and account teams experience and effectiveness varies from district to district.  Pressure is applied constantly and unrealistic goals set at times
advice_management: To local management. Do the right things right. Trust your people, do not micromanage, set the example,

summary: "Goal setting, review, reward process is still broken"
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Rising stock prices. Some bright spots in the company (C&E datacenter, cloud, machine learning, FPGA) and online tools (Office 365, CRM etc.). People are actually trying more to become 'one company.'
cons:
Windows is a sinking ship.  There are some bad managers. No upward direct feedback possible.  
Unpublicized, targeted layoffs are happening all over the place, impacting morale, focus and performance. This is especially so after Satya Nadella became CEO.
advice_management: People don't leave Microsoft; they leave their managers.  Get rid of bad managers to improve employee performance, loyalty, results.

Too many PM doing nothing and just slowing things down. Upper management has no vision.

Legacy code base and technology that no one else use outside of Microsoft. After working at Microsoft too long, you will become unemployable.

Toxic Politics drag everything down.
advice_management: Nothing. If it were heard, I wouldn't have left. Satya is doing the right thing but there are still too many dead weight to shed.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for less than a year
pros: Awesome people in the SF office. Comp is pretty good and the benefits are world-class including a healthy 401K match, tuition reimbursement, meals, gym reimbursement, 3 months paid maternity/paternity leave, retention bonuses and grants are easy to get. After stagnating for a decade, the stock appears ready to go up. Great work-life balance. Easy to jump to different departments (especially if you're willing to move to Redmond).
cons: 114K employees means there will be bureaucracy. If you're coming from a GSD startup mentality, the CYA, over-reporting, status meeting about status meetings could bug you. For the Bay Area, the pay is good but not amazing, there's no grand slam upside of a startup (even if those chances are slim) and it feels like the real career advancements are in Redmond.
advice_management: Keep on with the successful cloud transition and try to streamline some of the bureaucracy.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Good pay and benefits, wide range of products and businesses to work on, smart co-workers, ability of MSFT to "move the dial".
cons: Some MSFT businesses are growing (Azure, O365) while others are declining (Windows).  Life can be difficult if you are aligned with one of the declining businesses that is forced to reduce costs as a result of shrinking revenue.  Despite Satya Nadella's effort to change the culture, politics and fiefdoms are still deeply embedded.
advice_management: Take responsibility for and be more transparent about the constant stream of layoffs that have become core to the cost and talent management plans.  Failing to acknowledge layoffs hurts morale and creates uncertainty for remaining employees.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft  for more than a year

summary: "It's the engineers who make it great"
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than a year
pros: There is a very strong engineering culture in product development, with brilliant people doing great things.  The current culture from the top-down is the right one, and the focus on building great products over building something for a salesperson to sell is wonderful.  The company is moving towards embracing open source, which is huge.  Under the right management you can be empowered to act on things that matter to you, and that's critical.  The work is interesting, the problems are challenging, and the scale is one where millions of users are affected.  You can have a tremendous impact if you bias towards action, place yourself under good management, and work with engineering as much as possible.
cons: There are still remnants of "Ballmer's Microsoft" in places, where people are still acting in old ways.  Some people still don't "get" open source, and hate the very idea of it.  Luckily, you can usually ignore them and get your job done anyways.  When you have to do work that doesn't involve engineers, there's a good chance that you'll waste a lot of time talking about something without ever doing anything.  If you find yourself in that situation a lot, you need to change your role ASAP.
advice_management: Keep moving in the same direction, empower people who want to act on problems they know how to solve, and stamp out the remainder "Ballmer's Microsoft" by moving even more things to Open Source.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Great benefits, fair pay, focus on family and work/life balance.
cons: Politics, HR Policies restricting existing employees from moving to positions they are capable of. Easier to quit and come back than to get the correct position you deserve.
advice_management: Hire the right people for their job; ignore HR Requirements for promotions (time in role, current level, etc.) and focus on proven skills and capabilities

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft
pros: The culture is changing fast. From a monolithic battleship which is hard to change direction, to a fleet of small boats going into the same direction. Responding to market changes and customer feedback as quick as possible.
cons: The culture is not the same in all divisions. You need to choose the division that fits you well
advice_management: Love your transparency, become even more transparent

summary: "Things are very slow but changing under new leadership"
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft
pros: benefits, work-life balance, location, salary
cons: a lot of reorgs, and old folks hanging around without much talent. Things move very slowly
advice_management: Too many changes, reorgs cause a lot of confusion and practically no career growth

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Pay is good, and the benefits -- while not what they used to be -- are still good as well. For those that don't live near the main campus, the employee bus service is nice. Ability to telecommute/work from home on occasion is a plus on many days.
cons:
The company, and the Finance group along with it, is in the midst of transition. Specifically within the Finance pipe, there seems to be a lot of resistance or friction for movement. I get the sense that folks are waiting for the other shoe to drop, and are holding back from doing any more than they have to, and managing out of fear. 

And in spite of the comms to the contrary, managers are not interested in diverse opinions or the truth. If you don't agree and go along, you will not be here long. 

For newer/junior folks, it's probably fine. For senior managers, who have insulated and protected themselves, it's fine. For everyone in the middle, there is not a lot of opportunity for advancement or stability.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years

cons: Matrix'd.  Many overlapping teams.  Lots of redundancy.  New leadership is committed to rationalizing and streamlining this however.
advice_management: Continue to streamline and unify teams around common outcomes.

summary: "An Excellent Company that Takes Care of Its Employees"
job_title: Current Employee - Software Development Engineer (SDE) II
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Excellent Work Life Balance - Most teams are very flexible with working hours. As long as you get your work done and you're not completely AWOL you'll be fine. No questions asked when you want to take a vacation or need to take a sick day.

Good Career Growth - You may have to put in long hours if this is your priority but you absolutely can move up if you want to. Self-movers are encouraged on most teams
cons: Bureaucracy - With so many layers in the organization things are bound to get lost in the shuffle, or muddled by middle management. Most of the time it's fine and management does a good job shielding SDEs from churn, changing priorities, etc... but too often do developers get hit by reorgs, and if you're unlucky it can really affect your career path. It is hard to gain a lot of momentum and good feedback when you're being shuffled from place to place.
advice_management: Keep prioritizing the employees!

job_title: Former Employee - Principal Director of Engineering
main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: The engineers and senior leadership are top notch!  Great place to have huge impact on users across the world.  Awesome, clear company-wide mission that it truly inspiring!  Average pay and pretty good benefits (except healthcare, which was ruined by Obamacare for everyone).
cons: I have great respect for Satya and the culture shift he's initiated.  Unfortunately, mediocrity seems to have settled at the middle manager level, at least in some areas of the company.  Bad technology/strategy decisions made in the name of preserving fiefdoms and charter.  Political in-fighting for territory.  Leads stealing credit for minions work and blaming others for failures they should own responsibility for (usually behind their back).  Lack of leadership and zero integrity at the lead/development manager levels.  Perhaps just one really dysfunctional team amongst many, but in my 25 years as a software professional, literally the worst experience and most horrid disconnected power hungry leadership (and I use that term loosely) I've ever seen.
advice_management: Fire all the middle managers, just clean house and get rid of folks who are managers and not leaders.  They should be easy to spot - they will have taken zero accountability for any problems in their areas and have significant turn over, probably have bad poll results if their teams aren't numb to the lack of leadership by now.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Lots of good people
Really good benefits
Flexibility to work from home
cons:
Constantly changing. You could have several different managers in a short time frame. 
High pressure and stress. Work you do can be different than job description
Long hours. Expect 60+ as baseline. Fire drills
Review and rewards system
advice_management:
Invest in on-going manager training. Don't let someone become a manager just because its the next step. That's detrimental to the team
Innovate instead of follow the crowd. Find your path and stick to it

summary: "Great products. Lots of potential but very political."
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Plenty of jobs to choose from. They're are some great products to work on and a lot of talented people to learn from.
cons:
The flat organization creates an unhealthy political environment as your manager doesn't want more competition. Success at Microsoft is based on how well you play the politics. Nowhere to go in your career so people either leave or do the bare minimum once they realize that they're stuck at their level. The previous model was tougher but seemed fair. 
Boys' club. A lot of bias against women. This company is missing some check and balance. I've seen newly hired guys get promoted although they didn't deliver anything substantial for the product while women have to demonstrate potential, deliver, and they must do it flawlessly.
advice_management: With that much talent, Microsoft should be able to build tools that help HR identify bias i.e. All women in a team leaving within 6 months, and inconsistency at review time based on actual deliverables and impact.

advice_management: Cut the fat... aka middle management, who put process on top of process. Getting tasks done take far too much time and effort, which should be relatively easy, such as creating a PO.

cons: culture does not value sales organization, carry over from monopoly days means few sales leaders know how to sell in the new economy, inward focus and obsession with scorecards that are meaningless to customers
advice_management: Focus on enabling, empowering, and trusting sales organization dealing with largest customers.   Agility and flexibility to meet new challenges is extremely handicapped by existing approach

main_text: I worked at Microsoft
pros: Great benefits, broad range of opportunities.
cons: Often very long hours, review model stinks.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than a year
pros: There is freedom to learn nearly anything you find interesting. If you love technology, there is a lot of potential for growth. But you have to be self-driven, there won't be metrics for growth outside of billed hours and general community guidelines.
cons: Not enough information sharing! In services a lot of tasks and mistakes are repeated because of poor information sharing across projects.
advice_management: Make IP sharing a better system

summary: "Overall great benefits and opportunities to grow career."

cons: Lack of celebration and appreciation of employee tenure and milestones. Personal appreciation is missing. Review model still has a lot of flaws! Should be more part time work and job share opportunities.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
