advice_management: Treat employees fairly and cut out the politics and stack ranking

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft
pros: Great Benefit Package including fitness and vision
cons: Positive work environment has disappeared over the last three years -- now working for Microsoft Retail Stores is nothing but hi-pressure sales for any job position that is customer-facing (product advisor, service advisor, manager).
advice_management:
Stop beating staff daily with new metrics, new goals, and the need to always do better.  

Stop being open on Thanksgiving Day when sales are so slow its depressing to think how everyone could be with their families.

Close the stores in the evenings of July 4th so employees can celebrate this unique holiday with their families and friends.  Last July 4th after dark their were no customers.... none..but staff remained in the store while the Store Manager when to a Marlin's game...

main_text: I worked at Microsoft
pros:
Good salary and perks.
Nice offices.
Work with challenging and important technology 
Work with very smart people.
cons:
The company is very paternalistic. I haven't felt that ordered around since high school.
The harsh review cycle encourages bad behavior by employees.
Internal politics are quite brutal. People helping each other without some ulterior motive is rare.
Not recommended if you you are a mid- late career person.
The above noted pro - lots of smart people - leads to a lot of arrogance and hubris.
People are always *very* serious.
advice_management: You guys need to lighten up. The review system needs to be changed to allow employees to focus on the products and customers instead of playing Machiavellian games to get promoted.

summary: "Change may be the new norm but not a reality yet"
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros:
Satya is leading Microsoft to a new era of productivity, co-opetition, challenge & growth!
- Great benefits
- Great work/life balance
- Great diversity & values
cons:
- Stack ranking may be gone (on paper) but continues behind closed doors
- Re-org, Re-org, Re-org... just never cease. Strategic re-alignment is supposed to be a good thing but bad execution kills the game.
- Lateral move (to retain talent) is encouraged but the opportunity is rare because hiring manager is not embracing growth mindset. They'd rather hire someone who already has the skillsets instead of believing skills can be developed.
advice_management: Old habit is hard to change. Despite Satya having a bold vision for growth & change, people managers are still entangled in politics and bureaucracy; thereby impeding progress.

Free drinks
Orca card
cons:
Constant re-orgs and subpar job security

Too much politics , that you sometimes have to play the game

Not uncommon for people to work on livesite issues 90 hours a week (xbox)

People are overworked and produce low quality

No onboarding or training

Moving towards openspace neighborhood setups where productivity is hard to find

Use of ancient practices/technology

Traffic is getting worse every year, and expectations grow, so work/life balance almost doesnt exist.
advice_management: Stop burning out your employees and treat people like humans.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft
pros: Great culture, commitment to employee work life balance, competitive benefits, work with smart people, work on products and projects that make an impact in the world
cons: There is enormous amount of pressure to move to Redmond to advance your career. While there are roles available in the bay area the vast majority are in Redmond. Manager are generally are not supportive of distributed teams so to move up you move north.
advice_management: Think about enabling entire teams to be based in the bay area. Having bits and pieces of dev teams in the bay area but keeping all decision making in Redmond is not the same as having a team in silicon valley.

summary: "Azure Business Operations (Not for Technical Folks) STAY AWAY"
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros: Good atmosphere. Nice leadership team. They show that they care, and leadership team does have open door policy.
cons: If your technical and report to a business program manager then your career is in a slump. Being technical is looked down upon. If your manager is not technical, then you will never be appreciated by him or her. You will always be a threat to him since he or she is not technical. In order to stand out, you need to fudge all data and manipulate #'s via excel and present that raw data in MBR. At the end of the day its about making your boss look good!! And your manager has no appreciation for any of your work.
advice_management: Stop being so paranoid about losing your job, and actually pay attention to member of your teams who work really hard.

job_title: Partner Sales Executive - Senior Solution Specialist
main_text: I worked at Microsoft  for more than 5 years
pros:
Great people in general with a typical mix of less than competent people in some management positions.
Great benefits
Great compensation
Work life balance was typical for a tech company, sometimes you work a lot of hours to get what needs to be done done.
cons:
Too much control in the hands of some managers.
I was there seven years, exceeding quota, winning awards including Platinum club I had a great pipeline and my manager decided she wanted to do something different and I was gone.

Peter principle is alive and well
advice_management: Good, high performing people are hard to find and hire. Although my severance was very good I believe a lot more could have been done to help me find another role while still with the company

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Microsoft has really changed since Satya took over as CTO. Microsoft is very customer driven and innovation driven. We have super cool new tech coming out, and the culture is feeling more and more inclusive daily.
cons:
Still a bit slow moving. Promotions happen on average once a year, if at all. The majority of the leadership is middle-career, very few young leaders.
Still somewhat sales focused, but fortunately moving away from trying to get people to build Windows Phone apps.
advice_management: It would be great to see some younger technical leaders in management. Leading by promoting great examples would improve morale.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Amazing people. Amazing leadership. The company culture encourages making big bets. Many groups are operating like startups. Fantastic work environment. Genuinely cares about employees. Great opportunities to grow within the company. So many business - you never get bored - enterprise software, consumer, cloud, productivity, devices, gaming, and more.
cons: Highly competitive internally. Lots of very talented people everywhere in the company. Sometimes with big egos that can be a challenge. Company has many successful business, so sometimes it can take a while to learn how to navigate.
advice_management: Microsoft has a very unique corporate culture that's evolving currently for the better. Senior leadership, especially Satya, is driving some incredible changes to set the company for long-term success. While a lot of work is still in progress, my advice is to continue to accelerate this positive change throughout the company.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft  for more than 3 years

job_title: Current Employee - Senior Marketing Communications Manager
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Microsoft offers a ton of room for professional career growth, whether it be advancement or trying something new. The culture change that Satya is driving towards is a positive one--towards a growth mindset, where the "how" is valued just as much (if not more) than the "what"
cons: Despite the attempts to change the culture at Microsoft, there are still pockets of legacy employees who are in a fixed mindset, and struggling to adapt to the growth mindset culture. Legacy employees still like to "own" things (business processes, programs, etc). Also, given the sheer size of the company, it can be a struggle to create an agile environment. Work/life balance can be a struggle and requires constant prioritization (most managers welcome prioritization exercises).
advice_management: Continue rewarding those employees who are growth mindset employees, and continue to foster the new culture.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: I have followed the company for few years and worked for 13 years.It is very good in following through on capturing the customers.  It has seen shift from PC -> Internet ->Cloud focus pretty well.  Not too many companies that I know that has done this.
cons: Trying to get a good product that the customers love in the first release is a challenge for Microsoft.  I can list many products that took 3 releases to get there.  But the perception of the initial release sticks and take a long time to go away.
advice_management: Encourage innovation.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than a year
pros: The executive leadership is phenomenal. They have great vision and a deep understanding of the industry.  They promote integrity out of their sales professionals and truly care about providing a great software solution.
cons: Awful culture!  The legacy Microsoft sales reps seem out of date on technology and prefer the method of stabbing each other in the back in order to advance rather than simply out performing.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Room to move around, decent management and great benefits.  Especially like the vacation and medical benefits which remain competitive despite rising costs
cons: Stock performance until recently.  Too many layers of approvals/management and lots of politics to climb the ladder.  Would be nice for overachievers to know they could rise to AGC, but not at all guaranteed.  No one can even say how it happens
advice_management: Create a level between 66 and 67 so Sr Attorneys that do not manage (IC's) can get another bump, though not as huge as the bump to 67.  There is room for another level

main_text: I worked at Microsoft  for less than a year
pros: At Microsoft I would with some of the smartest people I had ever met. The company provides great benefits and is focused on giving back to the community.  Being such a large company, there are a lot of opportunities to move around. New executive leadership working hard to change the culture and adapt to a changing consumer market. Tough job considering how large the company is.  Access to a lot of resources and learning/professional development a top focus of management.
cons: It's a tough culture to break into it. Very engineering centric in product development (vs customer focused).  Found people to be very passive aggressive not giving direct feedback.  I also found the company to be very process heavy.  Every action/decision had to be backed up with significant data and done a certain way. People were slow to change direction/adapt.  Made it very difficult to work in a fast-paced industry.  Solutions to problems tended to be over thought and unnecessarily complicated.
advice_management: Encourage thinking that is outside of the box and allow changes in process/procedures.  Provide direct and timely feedback to employees.  Offer support when needed, but try not to stifle creativity.

Take this with a grain of salt. At Microsoft, the most important thing is what team you're on. I was not very excited about my particular team's work.

job_title: Current Employee - Senior Software Development Engineer
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Microsoft provides very compelling salary and benefits. It can be very enjoyable if you find the right team. I have seen very talented people who are very enjoyable to work with. But at the same time it is very common that you find your self in a team that they are not very professional. The most valuable aspect of working at Microsoft for me is access to many smart people in all different fields. You can get an expert opinion by just sending an email/IM to the right person.
cons: Getting promoted can be challenging and at times slow. Often I see people leave the company and they come back after couple of years and they get hired at much higher level with better compensation very different from the people who kept working in the company for that period of time continuously. Besides since Microsoft is super huge, sometimes great ideas dies in management ladder.
advice_management: I think they better focus on keeping and growing internal talents as opposed to trying to get employees from other firms and ending up paying more.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros: At Microsoft, you have the opportunity to work in many different fields at a very large scale.  Benefits and compensation are competitive, and it's a great location if you aren't interested in living downtown somewhere.  Work-life balance is considered important, so you won't find yourself working 12 hour days.
cons: With the removal of stack ranking, many of the common cons associated with Microsoft have been eliminated.  Most cons have been the result of my particular teams, but Microsoft does use some older technology for engineering which can be cumbersome.  Be careful if you sign up for a "quality" role as you may not be getting what you expect.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than a year
pros:
- Great salary, benefits, and bonus opportunities
- Reasonable work/life balance expectation
- No need to be a manager of people to advance your career (ICs do just fine)
- Ability to network is unrivaled
- Find your next job within the same company
cons:
- Still very sales-driven in many ways (many folks in leadership roles still drink the Balmer Kool-Aid)
- Certain technical roles do not have technical management
- All careers here will ultimately lead to Redmond
advice_management:
- Always lookout for your people first, even knowing/expecting that they will move on in less than five years in most cases
- Continue to strive for openness and open standards
- Keep the bar high for new hires

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Microsoft offers an exceptional benefits and compensation package.  I believe if you have a solid professional background you will be able to negotiate a good comp package + signing bonus.  Personally, I love to give to charities and truly appreciate the company match up to $15k.  Microsoft provides a good deal of opportunity for growth - if you take it.  Good technology.
cons: I found Microsoft to be too internally focused.  Limited opportunities for promotions for most people.  Many people are in the same level for years with limited promotion.  Calibration still exists, which wouldn't be a CON if it wasn't so subjective.  Basically, if you aren't playing an internally focused game, you will be at risk on your rewards.  Again - one of my PROS is the compensation.  Therefore, while there might be lots of back-stabbing politics to play on the corporate campus, you might still take home a good wallet.  Personally, I prefer to work around people with greater integrity.  Given Microsoft's focus on collaboration / productivity solutions, I was blown away by the demand for F2F meetings.  It takes a great deal of time to gain consensus and get things done.  Limited budgets.
advice_management: Empower your teams.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time
pros: Great benefits and work life balance.  There are a ton of smart people in the headquarters.

advice_management: Be more open to employees about how decisions are made and empower them more.  Ask them for their inputs

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft  for more than 5 years

advice_management: Don't keep playing catch-up. Do something where you are a first.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Great benefits and pay. The people I worked with were smart and had a great work ethic. I also enjoyed a good work life balance that was respected by my team.
cons: The promotion cycle was a bit slow. They still review their employees with a bell curve which leads to only a select few getting promotions and big bonuses (even though many people deserved them, the stack ranking only lets a certain number of people get promotions each year). I saw many of my colleagues leave before their signing bonus was up because of this.
advice_management: Keep going with direction Microsoft is heading! Embracing open source and other platforms while maintaining the business value we bring will make Microsoft great again.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time
pros: Amazing career growth opportunities. You get to work with the best/brightest in the world. The benefits are great and the salary is very good. The company is big and diversified enough that it's hard to get bored - plenty of opportunity to move to new areas with little hassle.
cons:

Need to continue on changing culture to foster better teamwork (vs. stepping on each other to get ahead).
Need to provide better work/life balance.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
Great company. The tide is truly turning from Redmond. Satya has the vision.
Deep opportunities in MCS PubSec - MCS has developed deep relationships over the years and the customers trust MCS with their most critical systems.
Pay is good. Benefits are excellent. You do not have to look far to find rock-stars on your team.
Lots of access to the MS stack, training, products.
The sky is truly the limit for career opportunities.
Tons of opportunities in the co as a whole to get involved, give back, do cool stuff with technology, ect.
cons:
Has transitioned over the years from a loss leader driving platform adoption to more of a body shop trying to fill all the slots created by YoY growth. Business metrics still rule the day, whereas a decade ago it was "are you happy doing what you are doing". You will still be asked, but the focus has shifted somewhat as the business has grown.

At the end of the day, your career decisions will take a back seat to whatever is easiest for the management chain. I saw people who were rock stars at the customer receive poor annual reviews after requesting new opportunities.Customer loves these people - called them out of critical to their vision. and they get the lowest review possible?

You will need to find opportunities for 'impact'. Simply providing excellent service to your customer, handling all the training, keeping up in your specialty is the bare minimum. To be fair that is communicated to you.

You will need to make sure you can stay engaged and build your network. Its critical in finding 

You may also find yourself looking longingly to Redmond, wondering what it is like to be a 'real' MS employee.
advice_management:
Ask your directs if they are satisfied where they are, with what they are doing day to day, and with the opportunities you can bring to them. Quit saying impact without defining it concretely, communicating exactly what that means to you, and how it can be quantified. Giving examples of what other people did may seem useful, but it doesn't always yield ideas which apply to our current situation.

Do the hard work. find out what you need form the field. make it concrete. allow people to choose from those opportunities if their current work doesn't provide one organically. Then, measure the impact of what you came up with. Work to improve that so it is more meaningful to the employee and less 'TPS' report-y.

summary: "Glassdoor Forced Me to Write This Review"
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft  for more than 10 years
pros: Microsoft is a great place to work.  I love it here.  It's not perfect, but no company is, but it's still a lot better than most companies I've worked for.  You can work on projects that impact the entire world.  If you don't like what you're current job, you can easily move to another team or division and keep all your seniority and benefits.  (And the benefits are great!)
cons: Microsoft can be a little insular and internally focused, although we try not to be.  Managers aren't uniform, there are good ones and bad ones everywhere, and you can get a bad one at Microsoft.  The environment can be very competitive, it's not for everyone (and getting in can be very competitive too).
advice_management: Keep up the good work.  Keep growing.  The company's really been headed in the right direction since Satya took over.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Fantastic company that works on innovative products. Tons of room for advancement out of college, and some really fantastic leaders in the senior leadership team. I'm never bored at work, which is a great thing!
cons: Some managers can be hit-or-miss, and your experience can be either really awesome or just ok depending on who your manager is.
advice_management: We re-org ALL THE TIME. This isn't great for productivity, but does keep everything "fresh". One re-org a year instead of 2 (or 4) would be a welcome change.

job_title: Current Employee - Software Development Engineer II
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros: A lot of very smart people to work with.  Life-work balance has become good.  The compensation and benefits are excellent.  If you can tolerate working on preexisting messes and remain productive, you can move up and on to working on some amazing stuff.
cons:
Advancement can be difficult, especially if you don't fit the mold; it's very dependent upon your immediate manager's opinion of you vs the level.  A lot is influenced by his ability to sell you to his peers and management.   
A lot of legacy around; you often have to earn your stripes per team trudging thru that before allowed to significantly contribute on a design level.   Lots of employees who have been there for years get the choice assignments.
advice_management: More clarity and parity across teams/groups is needed with regards to performance and promotion; current "published" skills etc. can be ambiguous.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft

cons: Terrible work life balance. Combative. Cultural fit demands you protect yourself from blame and push work to others.

summary: "Company is making changes for the better, but still has a lot to do."
job_title: Former Employee - Software Development Engineer II
main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Lots of different projects going on. Well established and stable. Good place to start your career. Lots of free software (and games if you work in Xbox).
cons: Lots of "old guard" employees that like doing things the way they've always been done. Lots of re-orgs. Lots of moves. Hard to get out from under poor management. Very bureaucratic.
advice_management: Buy out some of the old timers. Bring in some new blood. Be more open to new ideas.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great Account Teams and access to customers. Ton of solutions if you want to sell something different in a few years. So many choices and a lot of good people. Great from Sales to Services with a lot invested into growing you as an employee.
cons: Tuff place to sell at the same job for more than a few years. It can be feast or famine. Cloud has taken over, but on premise people seem to be second class citizens. Customers who just don't want the cloud can't get the conversation they need sometimes. Although the cloud is the future, sometimes it's not what the customer wants.
advice_management: Keep looking out for the employee! No one will ever care how much you know, until the know how much you care!

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
1. Benefits. Benefits. Benefits. Including pay.
2. Flexible schedules in most groups.
3. Company reinventing itself - new CEO making huge difference, setting the right strategy
4. Due to transformation, many opportunities to move around internally, to make an impact
5. Really great people - smart, motivated, innovation-minded, fun
6. Access to so many resources from technology to information to hardware to collaborators
7. Stock is up!
8. Many group embrace Agile methodology for engineering.
cons:
1. Transformation creates chaos and that can make for a tough work environment in many groups.
2. Cross-company top talent mgmt and retention is a stated goal but there are no real processes or advocacy in place for this (talent retention decision making is at the group level with no visibility to other groups at MS needing the same talent, skills, roles filled).
3. Re-orgs are a regular occurrence where your role, manager, division, etc. can change overnight.
4. Tendency to change a product or feature too soon or wait too long to change it.
5. Still not enough weight or influence given to Customer-focused or UX positions & talent.
advice_management:
1. Put a cross-company Talent Management practice in place asap.
2. Ensure all groups are aligned to Satya's strategy, vision, culture change, and practices quickly (e.g. Windows)

summary: "It all depends on the group you are in"
main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Benefits, campus, learning opportunities, broad scope and scale of experiences, bleeding edge technology and services on a big scale, the opportunity to work with some of the best and brightest people and teams.  Most teams and groups are good, some are incredible.  Your experience and growth can be merit based and not seniority based in the right groups and teams.
cons: Most of the groups and management is good, some are definitely stellar.  However, there are some bad groups, and bad managers that seem to rotate around.  Reorgs are sometimes highly destructive to products and services, and back channel prejudice is bad in some groups.  Don't tolerate weak ethics or leadership, if you see it or experience it, get out immediately, especially if it is new incoming management.
advice_management: They made a lot of changes to the review process after I left.  But it will take a six or seven review cycles to really see if the changes you made are going to make a difference.

summary: "Decent overall, sure thing in the end"

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Great people to work with, tons of opportunity.
cons: Upper management often doesn't understand what is happening at the lowest levels within the organization and often make decisions that those in the lower levels, don't approve of.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft part-time for more than 3 years
pros: Benefits here are great for both full and part time employees. Fun place to work even on the busiest days. Even the store meetings are fun. And for the first 3 years I was there, it didn't feel like I was just working retail - it felt like I was part of something bigger and a lot better.
cons:
We had a change in management at my location and the turnover rate spiked. For a long time, the most common reason employees left was a promotion within the company. But I saw more people leave last summer than I'd seen in the 3 years we'd been open. I can't speak for everyone, but for me, it was depressing to check my work email after a few days off to find out another co-worker was "no longer with the team". 

By the time I left, it no longer felt like I was part of something bigger; it was just another retail store with a revolving door of employees. It's hard to feel like you're part of a team when your "teammates" change several times a month. 

There were other changes I disliked, but it's difficult to explain those without getting too specific and losing any anonymity Glassdoor may give me.

If I had left a year earlier, this review would be 4 stars and my only complaint would have been the lack of communication among managers. But seeing things change the way the did has left me disappointed.
advice_management: I know the reasons for termination vary from employee to employee, but I think it's worth stepping back and figuring out why to turnover rate had risen the way out has. Because it's not just a matter of people moving on after a while; new people are being let go after less than a year.

summary: "Great for engineers. Marketing, not so much."
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Good work life balance and not a lot of stress. The company has more cash and more employees than it needs.
cons: If you're an Engineer this seems to be the place to work. For anyone else, not great. Seem to be moving to open floor plan vs offices.

summary: "Great place to go as a final career destination"
main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than a year
pros: stability, solid benefits, competitive salary, being part of a well known brand. fantastic retirement perks.
cons:
the culture feels old and worn. yet there is a snobbiness about microsoft that they can't seem to shake. they also value age and experience over what seems like everything else.

microsoft is no longer the cool kid on the block---even though the people who have been at microsoft for decades still seem to think they are. 

also, microsoft can be a a bully. and not in a self-aware way.
advice_management: find and retain your new, fresh talent. advanced age and experience shouldn't be the two primary factors for fitting in to your culture. its intimidating to be a young person at this company and you're constantly being treated like a kid --- even if you have 10+ years of experience.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft
pros: Great company with many skilled people.  Lots of room for growth.  The resources available (such as libraries of info/data) are astounding.
cons: Duplicate roles seem to be common.  Coordination across work teams is difficult, but is a great opportunity.
advice_management: Continue to evolve the company, and build connections across the groups.  Good progress is showing already.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft
pros: Benefit, work environment, flexibility, exposure to different areas.
cons: Salary/Position not necessarily reflect what actual work has been done.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros: If you're looking for the mythical software team with a real focus on good work/life balance, in my opinion Microsoft is well worth looking at. No longer the cool kid on the block, but doing some great, innovative work and, rather than being able to make their employees instant millionaires, are focused on good work/life balance and very good overall compensation.
cons: It's a huge company, and there is certainly bureaucracy. And of course, your experience of the company is heavily influenced by whether you have a great (or not so freat) manager. Your mileage may vary.
advice_management: It's critical that the people who are managers are the right folks. Nothing worse than folks that consider being a manager to be their path to promotion, but don't love being a lead and making their employees great. There are still TERRIBLE managers at Microsoft who are allowed to persist.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years

cons: If you're on a team where things just don't feel right, move on. At Microsoft, you need to be aware of your surroundings, the politics of your group and the groups with which you interact. It pays to be politically savvy.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Microsoft is an exciting place to be these days. Lots of new opportunities to truly reach a global audience. You feel that you are making an impact. Also, for many roles great flexibility to work from home and support for flexible schedules.
cons: Opportunities to advance are more challenging for remote employees, but I don't think that's a problem unique to Microsoft. The competitive nature of the company can make it tough at times to have your voice heard. Numerous turf battles within the company can be draining.
advice_management: I would ask management to remember the other groups besides engineering that provide vital contributions to the product. Make sure those concerns are taken into account.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft

cons: laid back; taking a lot of processing time for everything

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft
pros: Great benefits and opportunities to learn new skills
cons: Very political and top management slow to move

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for less than a year
pros: It's splendid for someone looking to coast and get some good compensation while doing so. Good benefits, free drinks, and work-life-balance is too good to be true.
cons: If you actually care about building products that make sense and have an impact, then this is not your place. It's the tech-equivalent of a Detroit car manufacturer: slow, boring, silo'ed, and process-oriented. You don't get any end-to-end responsibilities unless you've been there for 20 years and have finally 'served' enough time to make Corporate Vice President. Even then, there's a ton of pointless politics and absolute lack of regard for how simple the offering should be and how to serve the customer. Half the time, nobody knows what the hell is going on in the organization. The company is so big and bloated that there's so much duplicate work going on, and zero ownership given to young, motivated, smart people. You're expected to 'shut up and learn', and don't suggest or question anything until you've been around for as many years as it takes for someone to forget when you joined. Long-story-short: terrible company for someone looking to make difference in the world around them.
advice_management: Don't just pay talented people. Invest in them. And not through those BS company-wide HR 'initiatives', but on a micro-level. Alter the structure of the company so that people on the younger and hungrier side gain a lot more product ownership and end-to-end responsibilities, and stop permeating the idea that 'knowledge is king' and that 'tenure is above all'. They're not. Getting things done is far more important, and making mistakes along the way and learning from them is not only expected...but should be encouraged.

summary: "Amazing people in spite of middle management."
main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Terrific technical talent and seemingly unlimited resources. The CEO and his directs are strong champions for reinventing Microsoft. Got to work on software used by a billion people.
cons:
Brutal infighting at the middle management level. There is a preference to chasing what partners want, rather than solving problems faced by really Microsoft customers. 

Benefits and pay are okay, but they're not kept up.
advice_management:
Know who your customers are. Listen to your customers. 

Microsoft is an amazing  company in its own right, stop trying to be Google or Apple.

job_title: Former Employee - Software Development Engineer In Test (SDET) II
main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Good Cross Team movement
Great respect for employees
Smart people around. 
Redmond is great affordable place to live.
cons: If you want something more different look at   venture funded startups as soon after the series-A close as possible.  There will be more room for you to do things "beyond your pay grade" at a big company and less for negative politics.
advice_management: Politics is everywhere, its just a matter of how much of it is visible to you (and how much you are interested in seeing it). The only way not to get involved in politics is by only associating with your work, and not get involved in anything that is not directly related to your work.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft
pros: Good Company to work for.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: The breadth of products and services, innovation, talent, resources and overall benefits make this a great place to work. The leadership team, company strategy and "learning mindset" culture are well positioned to take Microsoft into the future. The company's focus on empowerment has resulted in thoughtful investments in philanthropic giving which could really move the needle in the communities that stand to benefit.
cons: Mobility is tough, its very hierarchical and process heavy. The lack of agility to respond to market opportunities or simply have a business review that isn't weighted down by process can make the company feel like the post office at times. There are fewer job openings than in the past and you must have an advocate/sponsor to progress. Doing good work isn't enough and despite more talk of valuing diversity, women and minorities are often the ones who lack  the needed advocacy/sponsor to move up or simply stay in the ranks.
advice_management: Job rotation, internships and other ways that allow employees to grow their skillets are sorely needed. This isn't about training. The company does a great job of that. It's about opportunity. There's great institutional knowledge within the employee base but without more/different opportunities to move to, people will leave. Not because they want to but because they feel there is no other choice for meaningful employment.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft
pros: Nice for beginners. Great Internal opportunities.
cons: Top Management heavy. No room for growth as a contractor.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than a year
pros: Great benefits, competitive compensation package. Great relevance on the market and great to have on the resume.
cons: Difficult ways of working and culture. Satya is really doing a good job in making the company more human, but there is still a ton of progress to be done as most of the employees have 5-10 of in-house work experience so not something you manage to change overnight.
advice_management: Be open, human and kind to employees. Support transitions and understand the origin of frustrations. Work together with your employees on achieving things together.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros: Company culture is changing for good reasons under the new leadership.
cons: Too many levels within the company. Everyone tries to prove themselves, which results in stepping on each other's work.
advice_management: Lean team would result in higher job satisfaction, less chaos, and greater productivity.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft

summary: "Good place to start out for college students"
main_text: I worked at Microsoft part-time
pros: Good pay, flexible with school schedule, benefits for part time & full time employees, and exciting atmosphere. Nice perks here and there when new products come out.
cons: In the end, it is retail. You can work a lot of hours depending on the season, but hours can get cut and work can be boring when holiday seasons are over. With that being said, it can get boring when it is not too busy. Also, you have to deal with the occasional Apple fanatics that want to test you.
advice_management: Keep thinking of ways to improve employee morale. Continue giving opportunities to every employee so that they can help out in the different teams within the store.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft  for more than 10 years
pros: lot of opportunities in working on different technologies/domain,
cons: every decision needs multiple meetings and many people, highly bureaucratic, top management GM and above are political. recently too much continuous layoffs
advice_management: empower the ICs and front line managers on decision making, reduce decision points, stop continuous  layoff

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros: can work on very public projects.
cons: bad managers and program-managers can cause late hours with little learning.  'Those who don't know the past are doomed to repeat it' can be said often about the place.  The SDET removal caused a lot of institutional lack of care about testing and regression prevention.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: There are some very smart people, and some of the work is interesting.
cons: The company is so inwardly focused.  Decisions are made based on what lets managers and execs check boxes on the internal scorecard and get their bonuses.  Employees are still ranked and reviewed on a curve, no matter what the company says about having changed the system.  And many people are still treated very unfairly.  The people who thrive at Microsoft are those who absolutely drink the koolaid, and focus on managing up.
advice_management: Care about your customers and your people.  Stop pretending to care . . . actually do the right thing even if it means you're not checkin your box on Kevin Turner's scorecard.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Great pay and benefits
They have a massive poll once a year and they really seem to listen to our responses
When you have a good manager, you are set up to do well and advance in pay/responsibilities
cons:
Management is a toss-up. In my 5 years with MS I've had 9 managers. 1 was excellent, 2 were decent, 2 were a nightmare, and the rest were forgettable. Of those 9 managers, 6 of them were in a different location, and 4 of them I never even met in person. This makes it really hard come review time.

They have a weird review system where basically a certain percentage of the company has to be let go every year. This makes for a lot of competition, obviously, and also makes it hard to really help or collaborate with teammates, since you're basically doing everything you can to not be that bottom group of people.

They claim that it's easy to move around the company, but I've found that to be very untrue. Once I was hired, I stayed in my role for 2 years, became a subject matter expert, and then tried to move on to the next thing. I wanted to expand my knowledge, keep learning, and try something new. It's been 3 years since I started trying, and I'm still in that same role I started in. And I have great reviews, so you'd think other teams/managers would be interested in me. But the reality is that moving from one team to another is incredibly hard because the way we are trained here makes us incredibly knowledgeable in one small field, and basically clueless in everything else. I wish I had a broader knowledge base. This also makes it hard to find new opportunities outside of the company.
advice_management: Stop doing remote management. If my manager can't pick me out of a lineup, how is it OK for him to determine my pay/bonus/ranking? We need relationships with the people that manage us, and that just can't really be done well over Skype.

summary: "Great place to work, but depends on your career stage"
main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Great work life balance, salary and benefits and very smart and friendly peers. People really care about the company and stay on for a long time.
cons: Bureaucratic - sometimes painfully slow. Decisions can take a long time and it can get frustrating at times. Growth can be quite slow if you are in one of the traditional teams like Office. Not everyone works equally hard and that can be frustrating.
advice_management: Weed out the non performers religiously, and make a performance driven culture. Encourage people to rotate within the firm more often and less re-orgs.

summary: "Great company if you're on a well managed project"
main_text: I worked at Microsoft  for more than a year
pros: Some of the most talented people I've ever had the opportunity to work alongside with. Input was welcome from all levels and all disciplines. Ownership of certain project aspects was encouraged. Credit was given and recognized by those who deserved it. The group I was in operated akin to a Special Operations Group. If they brought you in they knew that you were good at what you did, so they allowed you to designate your own targets independently without having to get full authorization from Command.
cons: Not all management was as good in all studio groups (YMMV). Some contractor relationships with FTEs were strained because of their transient situation ( Don't get too close to that Dude he's out of here in a few months or until a re-org occurs). Conversion to FTE from a contractor position although a possibility is something I never saw first hand (some kinda unicorn scenario)
advice_management: My Management group was phenomenally awesome sauce!!! Door kickers and Heart breakers each and every single one of them. Nothing but props to those that see the value in a unorthodox approach and are willing to give it a try, because it's another potential solution.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 8 years
pros: People are exceptional.  Mature employee management systems and culture.  Growth mindset.
cons: Stuck in 2000s culture.  Lack of genuine collaboration.  Not hungry enough.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft  for less than a year
pros: Started as a vendor and was converted to full-time.

summary: "Company used to be great, everything has changed"
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft  for more than 3 years
pros: Great wage for very little responsibility. Great benefits, pays for parking, and really teaches you skills to use in a real IT role.
cons: Culture has moved to a sell first mindset, and you'll be pushed to make sales quotas, even if you weren't hired to do that. Management has no idea what they are doing, cronyism is ripe.
advice_management: Look at who is doing the best job, not that kid you used to work at best buy with when it comes to promotions. Don't just see the forest for the trees.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time
pros: Good work life balance, interesting and challenging work, cutting edge technology, super-smart people, global reach
cons: Definitely not a place for women to work, the management really tries to show they are fixing the culture but consistent gaffs like the XBOX party and feedback from other women in the company show that there is a toxic culture that persists. Additionally the culture is very old boys network and can be hard to succeed unless you are lucky enough to form good personal connections. Ideas aren't evaluated on merit but on political prowess and connections.
advice_management: Embrace the vision of agile development. Let go of the antiquated idea that the old timers know everything. Take risks, do new and wonderful things. Fix your women problem, not only are you not recruiting women you're losing them faster than you can admit.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Microsoft is stable, treats their employees well, pays their employees well, get to work with a lot of smart people, free beverages, reimbursement up to $800 for fitness expenditures, top notch benefits, huge positive impact in people's lives, lots of opportunities if you look, can be a great experience if you find a good manager.
cons: Easy to get lost in a large group, terrible if you don't have a good manager, emphasis is often too much on process, work life balance still isn't great, some groups aren't receptive to new ideas, and as a rule collaborating cross group is challenging.
advice_management: Listen, support, encourage, foster creativity and collaboration, channel passion rather than squelching it.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Great people, good company that takes good care of employees in general,
cons: Politics - anytime you have a juicy project watch out, someone else is going to make a play for it. Limited upside - Microsoft hasn't been able to really reward people relative to companies like Google or Amazon.
advice_management: Take active role in managing careers of people, especially your winners, like GE or IBM do

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Love learning all the new technology in the cloud.  There is a lot of opportunity to grow your career.  And there's a lot of different departments such as consulting or product management.
cons: Sometimes reviews could be tough.  You have commitments and you have utilization that are used to base your bonus calculations and depending on your level, you have tougher challenges.
advice_management: Management has been good and fair.  Especially now that they removed stack ranking, people have been much happier at all levels.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft
pros: Great place to work. Exciting.
cons: Same as any company of similar size and stature
advice_management: Keep it up

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft  for less than a year
pros:
Great team
Awesome Managers - they care about us
cons: None that I can think of at this time

job_title: Current Employee - Ecommerce Category Site Merchandiser: Windows Phone
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than a year
pros: The Microsoft online store team does a great job keeping the goals clear and rallying together to reach those goals.
cons: The tools used for the Microsoft online store are very outdated and manual. In order to measure site preforamnce one has to do hours of manual work.
advice_management: There is not enough focus on customer experience and customer journey. I think the culture of the company should focus more on customers.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Good Salary, Benefits.  Opportunity to work with product development and manage a global business.  You can move around different parts of the company to find your passion and a good fit.
cons: Can be very political, you need to have a good relationship with your manager and your skip level managers support.  While stack ranking apparently is no longer used, there is still an unfair process of evaluation that is not based on accomplishment of goals.
advice_management: Keep reviewing and changing the performance evaluation process.  Learn to value employees for their contribution rather than hearsay

summary: "Great Company with Fantastic Benefits, Overly Bureaucratic"
job_title: Current Employee - Senior Sales Excellence & Strategy Manager
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than a year
pros: Microsoft has a great reputation and offers fantastic benefits. Strong leadership corporate strategy sets Microsoft up for many future successes, especially within the Cloud arms race.
cons: Microsoft is overly bureaucratic, which isn't a surprise for a company of it's size, but it makes it difficult to get work done in a timely manner at times. In most cases, all roads lead to Redmond, so   it can be career limiting to be in other locations if relocation is not an option or want.
advice_management: Focus on process efficiency and reducing unnecessary efforts that drag down employees productivity. It would also be beneficial to be more open to a less Redmond centric requirement for US resources.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft
pros: great work life balance provided
cons: not many career growth opportunities

main_text: I worked at Microsoft
pros:
Good atmosphere. Relaxed approach.
People were very nice and always ready to provide insight.
cons: Nothing to write home about.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft
pros: Global organization and organization culture
cons: Layoffs and uncertainty at times

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft
pros: Amazing place to work at I absolutely love it.
cons: Still implementing new systems

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft  for more than 8 years
pros:
1. Good Benefits
2. Flexible working schedule
3. Exciting time to be part of the "new" Microsoft
4. Strong company vision
cons:
1. Field Sales Growth numbers are way too aggressive
2. Sales Team talent is a bit of a joke, nothing but product bells and whistle sellers
3. Sales is directed to transform, but little to no sales transformation is happening in the field
4. Field leadership sits behind spreadsheets and spends little to no time with customers. Very removed from their teams.
advice_management: Transform your sales teams.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft
pros: Benefits, nice office, they applied my GC
cons: Salary, not fun job, stupid mamgement

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than a year
pros: Great projects, strategic initiatives, progressive company and of course fantastic benefits. Very smart and driven people
cons: sexism and ageism in the workforce. If you complain, you are marked. constant change makes employees fearful and therefore less collaborative, more defensive and feeling as though "I must succeed at all costs". Review process has NOT changed. On paper yes, but not in reality. If you make many small impacts the work is dismissed for those who may drive one large project. Evaluations are not focused on holistic impact, peer reviews are selective, and can be excluded. process can be very subjective with no recourse. Basically, my experience was if you are sub-ordinate and do not have an engaged or support manager you literally are screwed.
advice_management: listen to your surveys and reviews of managers. If there are complaints, work to coach the manager. not all successful ICs are meant to manage. Look at why you keep crappy employees and get rid of great people. you are quickly becoming the place everyone leaves and refers to as " it was great once to work there, but glad I'm gone or I wouldn't go back". You are also eliminating a solid and seasoned workforce and fearfully keeping them at bay from not suing do to thoughts of being blackballed. Recurring theme I've heard (and experienced first hand) as an ex-microsofty

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft
pros: Nice environment, good people, nice surroundings, and overall pretty sweet place to work at. The vibe is nice and its not in Silicon Valley, if you're into that.
cons: I think that you just have to be very open minded in a lot of differnt things. This isn't really a con but just something to be prepared for.

summary: "Great company, excellent benefits, but pay is tricky"
main_text: I worked at Microsoft
pros: Great company to work for, industry-leading benefits, 401k 50% match, ESPP etc, lots of opportunity to move up and grow but...
cons: Leveling competition within the company is a huge pain, it's hard to move up even if you do great work. I've heard people leave to go elsewhere and then rejoin at a higher level. If you don't like what you're doing or not performing well, instead of helping you find another opportunity on the same team or on another team, they may ask you to politely resign. Big teams = low employee morale and lack of fun culture. The smaller the team, the better and more close everyone is, as it grows, you can pretty much forget about that connection.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft
pros: Best place to work hands down
cons: No real cons at all.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Long term vision of company is pretty clear.  Talking the right things
cons: Individual managers can make or break your overall effectiveness

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 8 years
pros: competitive salary and benefit. great leadership in general
cons: too many divisions/team with conflict of interests

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than a year
pros:
Great learning experience over Microsoft Products.
Good company within the store.
Really exciting new product reveals, always nice to see new Microsoft Products release, and it's a plus to be able to test drive devices that aren't officially in the market yet.
cons:
Management have had personal issues that got in the way of the job environment.
The Microsoft Store was within the mall, so the store can get a little rowdy sometimes.
Difficult to achieve promotions without having personal relationships with management outside of store.
advice_management: Schedules and breaks were very lenient, but sometimes employees can't catch a break over favorites. Management played favorites with the employees.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for less than a year
pros: Great pay, good work environment, amazing leadership, great benefits, and a growth mentality is enforced. They are really focused on taking care of the customers, they go out of their way for customer satisfaction. Everyone in leadership here is honest, caring, and a joy to be around. I've been here for 4 months and I've grown in many areas. One thing I love about leadership is they care about you as a person and not just an employee.  So often times they will ask questions to make sure you're at your best so you can excel. I watched my trainer get promoted in the short time I've been here and they encourage people to move up in the company. My hiring manager actually pulled me to the side and showed me some positions to apply for. They are amazing here.
cons: There is nothing bad about working at Microsoft. it's retail so you have to hustle to make sales but it is easily the best retail work environment I've ever experienced.
advice_management: Continue to be considerate,loving and motivating.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros: We enjoy the working atmosphere and the friendly staff around the company. Almost the salary is descent.
cons: No major downsides except for the promotion structure where best candidates are not always those hired.
advice_management: The recruitment process shall not be based only on the education path but also on hands on experience acquired at Microsoft.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Growth areas are very rewarding to work for. Wonderful impact opportunities at Azure, Apps. good people, very smart leadership.
cons: The company still hasn't quite solved the issue of how to create collaborative culture, especially in the PM organization. Individual impact is still the primary thing that is valued / helping others is mostly paid lip service to. Good managers do encourage, but those are seldom/adhoc.
advice_management: Do less moonshots, really embrace quick iterations/lean stuff. Keep working on encouraging collaboration...

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great Leadership and Culture, Good pay, good benefits, great opportunites
cons: Still a lot of pressure to perform, differentiated rewards, always managing low performers out

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros: Definitely huge and allows for someone to make a true global impact if you find the right team.  Be sure to research the line of business and trajectory of the product you will support.
cons: Total lack of centralized anything , makes relationship building the only way to be effective.  The place is held together by brain power and attitudes.
advice_management: There's still a lot of duplication in the company, even though there has been a dramatic improvement in the past 24 months.  Efficiency across divisions is lacking.

summary: "Microsoft takes care of its employees! Love this company"
main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than a year
pros: Collaborative environment, workplace flexibility (depending on your role), and the best benefits you will ever find in a private sector company. It's also been aggressively innovating now that it's lagged behind in the consumer electronics space. Exciting place to be, and definitely the best company I've worked for. I felt like they definitely took care of me as an employee.
cons: High turnover within the company, at least with younger employees. Many of the people I worked with in the company ended up leaving to pursue other opportunities. Also, work-life balance can sometimes be skewed, and you really need to set boundaries because they will otherwise swallow you whole, if you let them. They weren't so great about letting me work remotely when I had to pick up and move out of the continental US, but I also don't blame them, it was a big change in distance. That said, I do wish they took employees trying to come back more seriously!
advice_management: If you want to decrease turn-over, there needs to be more flexibility in locations. Young employees are still trying to figure out where to settle down, and it doesn't help either party if the employee has to quit a great job just to live near home. Also, rely more on young employees to contribute -- many of my peers felt like they were being lectured to and like their ideas were not taken seriously. Luckily I had a great team, but not everyone could say the same.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
Benefits, benefits, benefits.  It's a shame the Company isn't better at touting how incredibly rich the benefits/perks are to external candidates. 

The culture is changing to be more collaborative and innovative.
cons:
There are still people with a "legacy" mindset (political, risk adverse and "comfortable") who need to be pushed out so the employees truly interested in seeing Microsoft succeed can push through. 

Overall, I found the people managers at Microsoft to be lacking.  Most managers (in my experience) are not interested in propping others up or improving their leadership skills - they are more interested in their own careers.
advice_management:
First, pay attention to Glass Door. :)  I know first hand there is little interest in feedback but if you want to compete, you may want to pay attention.  

Place more value on attributes like "making others great" - especially among your management team.  Performance should be tied not only to what is delivered but a manager's contribution to the Company by moving top performers into other roles where they can stretch and grow.

Implement an Internal Mobility program that enables employees to easily find jobs internally.  It's surprising anyone is willing to navigate our current system when they could just answer the phone and leave to a competitor.

pros:

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros:
A lot of ways to grow technical knowledge
Wide area of exposure to technology
cons:
Depends on the project - may be stuck with old technology
Review model is blocking the growth (even the new model).
Have to be in position for X years to be promoted to next level.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Good benefits, good work environment
cons: Was part of lay off in 2014.  Seemed to be a poor method for keeping the best talent, and getting rid of the dead wait.
advice_management: Do a better job keeping talent

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft
pros: MS is a great place, they take really good care of their employees. Gives you everything you need to be productive.  It's very easy to stay here forever, because you can switch teams if you get bored and need totally different kind of experience. Switch from web-dev to machine learning to game design etc
cons: If you are in a traditional team, things can move really slow

main_text: I worked at Microsoft  for more than 3 years
pros: Exposure to exceptional talent in a passionate work environment.  Customers were highly motivated to engage with our team to drive value and Return on Investment.
cons: The pace that was required to meet quarterly earnings expectations were, at times out of sync with our market segments sales cycle.  This created unintended sales negotiations mistakes that did not favor either side.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time
pros: Lots of fun intern events such as hike to Mt.Rainier, Sounders game, Boeing tour, etc. Very friendly and intelligent people in MSR.
cons: I worked independently for the project I worked on. It would have been better if I had a chance to collaborate more with other engineers.
advice_management: MSR was very organized in general and I didn't really have an issue with their management

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros: Every team is different in microsoft but lot of freedom and challenging problems to work on.
cons: Some process but otherwise very smart people
advice_management: Reduce bottlenecks and improve the process and more bottom up products design.

summary: "PM at MS a long time ago"
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft
pros: Smart coworkers. Nice campus and perks. Everyone uses your product. Dogfooding.
cons: High meeting overhead. MS strategy tax. A lot of smart people doing stupid things collectively.
advice_management: You have to actually compete. The mothership name alone won't win new markets.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 8 years

summary: "Excellent company that cares for its employees"
main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time
pros:
- Awesome total compensation: salary, bonus, stock
- Easy to move within the company
- Does good things for the community: Giving Campaign
- Excellent health insurance, vacation, perks
cons:
- Large organization, can be frustrating during re-orgs
- Not innovating as much in certain spaces
- Lots of politics and management heavy, hard to get things done quickly without approval

main_text: I worked at Microsoft  for more than 5 years
pros: They drive employees to grow and improve themselves through training and moving into other roles.  You're surround by lots of really smart people.
cons: The politics are thick and rampant.  In an effort to improve and show management that you're making an impact in the company, many will often backstab and/or throw their colleagues under the bus.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Microsoft is chock full of passionate, intelligent folks who are driven to succeed. Although they have been waning in recent years, Microsoft can still boast some of the best corporate benefits to be found anywhere.
cons: Microsoft seems to have lost some of its mojo. Satya Nadella seems well suited to recapture the magic, but down in the trenches there is still some latent tension as a result of self-protectionism that stifles not just innovation, but also just shipping and marketing solid products.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros: Health Insurance, Pay, Benefits and work life balance. Always new positions to progress into people are always moving around...very growth oriented company.
cons: Not many bad things to say. If you do not like a fast paced environment that is always innovating and changing then Microsoft is not for you.
advice_management: Keep ding what you are doing. Maybe take more advice from employees as they are the ones doing the actual job and their opinion has a lot of validity to it.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Very smart, talented, engaged people.  Great projects to work on.  Endless learning/growth opportunities.  Great perks such as bus transportation.
cons: The only con is the location and commute time.  It's super expensive to live close to the Microsoft campus, so we choose to live 20+ miles away, but Microsoft does provide a bus service, so that helps.
advice_management: Keep focusing on being all inclusive of all developers, partners, customers no matter what device they use... love it!

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft
pros:
Easy to ramp up.
Friendly environment for new comers and family, good work-life balance
cons: No technical challenges or training, pay is not fair among all candidates sharing same level, a lot of re-org

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft
pros: Salary, Company culture, challenging work
cons: Schedule and travel can be challenging

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft
pros:
Benefits
Compensation
Passion from organization around making everyone better as a team
cons:

Team mindset shifts blame and responsibility to those capable vs those underperforming

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Flexibility, autonomy, and varied responsibilities
cons: Ageism, getting large company mentality, slow to adapt.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years
pros: I was on a great team of people with an admirable manager. That makes all the difference in the world at a large company. I worked with extremely smart, driven, talented people.
cons: At the time, company direction was not clear but since the new leader, they are headed in a clear direction.
advice_management: Lay out clear goals for everyone and celebrate successes.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft  for more than a year
pros: Great place to work. Lots of interesting work. Company is going in the right direction.
cons: Its a slightly old style company. Main location is in Redmond so the bay area is not the best place to be in for growth.
advice_management: Increase bay area population. Make the bay area be a bigger satellite so folks have a lot more options here in the bay area. This is critical to hire great talent.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft  for less than a year
pros: Great benefits and pay. Microsoft is striving forward to be more open and shed off the pre-existing bureaucracy. At the same time, they're working hard to make better and more secure products .
cons: Nothing of much significance so far. The only con I see so far is that because of the size, it will be difficult to navigate through stuff initially.
advice_management: None.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for less than a year
pros: The pay and benefits are good. Opportunity fort career advancement exists if you are willing to put in the effort.   Job stability is very good too.
cons: The company and projects and technology are not generally revolutionary or cutting edge. Processes are a little bureaucratic as expected in a large company.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft
pros: great culture, intelligent people, work-life balance
cons: not enough sharing and coordination between different teams

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time
pros: Good future state plan. Strong devices platform in XBOX and Surface. Strong software platform win windows and azure.
cons: Slow to get there... painfully slow.  A lot of older workers who are waiting out their last few years of employment
advice_management: Force communication between the middle level management teams.  Too much independent thought going on in each organization and not enough working together and synergy

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft
pros:
Amazing culture and great people. High collaborative environment, everyone is willing to help each other succeed.
Always something cool going on.
cons: Microsoft is a big company. You do have to do a lot of self promoting to make sure you don't get lost in the shuffle.
advice_management: Keep doing what you are doing!

main_text: I worked at Microsoft  for more than a year
pros: Good Company with interest in latest Technologies.
cons: New Recruit needs time to learn the Company Dynamics. Need to be in a good Team with Clear directions.

main_text: I worked at Microsoft
pros: The company has great culture. You get a chance to work on products used by millions of users so your changes can be seen in the real world.
cons: There is a lot of process in the software development process that add unnecessary overhead to the system.
advice_management: The should have fewer layers of managers and replace them with engineers who code.

summary: "Great place to work,  but a huge company"
main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than a year
pros: The benefits are top of the line.  Between health benefits, to intramural sports, to commuter options.  Plus we love the area.
cons: I didn't find the work to be as engaging as it could have otherwise been.  It is definitely like working in a huge corporation.
advice_management: I felt like a little more mentoring and training would have been very beneficial.  I didn't feel like there was much opportunity to advance.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Pay is great, benefits are good
cons: Expectations unrealistic, out of country workers hard to work with, HR incompetent. Newcomers will be expected to climb the ladder, but reorgs will get in the way as will people sticking to only doing things the old ways. You'll be asked to drive and come up with ideas, but having to deal with team projects will get in the way of actually accomplishing anything.
advice_management: Fire the HR staff, hire people in HR who will take responsibility for their work

main_text: I worked at Microsoft  for more than 8 years
pros: People are a key asset
cons: Career movement. Do it early in your role and often.
advice_management: Focus on the cross departments. Seriously - 1 Microsoft. Get yourself out of the fog.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros: You will be judged by your overall performance at the end of the year. If you contribute a lot, you will get a large bonus; a little, and you will get a small or no bonus. You won't get credit for attendance. Company's commitment to work/life balance is not rhetoric.
cons: Lots of emails, distractions. Lots of overhead to ship product. Will move bigger, more important mountains, but will not move them as quickly. If a small company environment is what you crave, this is not the place for you.
advice_management: Focus on day to day engineering and customer satisfaction - not necessarily "innovation". Chrome is not winning against IE because it is "innovative", but because it is faster, more reliable, and implements basic features well.

summary: "Microsoft has reinvented itself, inside and out"
main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Awesome place to work, specifically within Xbox. So many internal programs focused on diversity and inclusion. I've been fortunate to work within an organization lead by true people-managers that genuinely care about managing people and careers, not accepting a manager position as a selfish career-advancement. People often talk about "having impact" as a reason to look for gigs at smaller companies. I'd argue that you have even more opportunity for impact at a company as large as MSFT because of the inherent scope and reach that the company already has - leverage it, don't fear it.
cons: Like many places - there's always more to do. It's fast-paced, demanding, and frugal. As a budget manager and strategist, I always feel like we're asked to do more on less... but that's a healthy exercise for any responsible company to go through on a continuous basis.
advice_management: (I'm a white male) Continue investing in diversity and inclusion, not only for customers but employees.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than a year
pros: If you want to be part of the data driven culture change at Microsoft consider working in the Azure AppPlat AUX team. This is where the innovation is happening and research is at the heart of it.  Great culture, fun people, and excellent opportunity for researchers to impact with foundational research that makes a difference.
cons: There are politics, but that's the way it is anywhere.
advice_management: None

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft
pros:
Ability to Impact
Feel empowered
Strategic thinking
Ability to build teams
Compensation
cons:
Barriers to get to next level/Director
Work-life balance
lack of coaching/guidance to get to next level
Fewer opportunities to advance in Individual contributor role

advice_management: Create more opportunities for individuals with good track record to promote to Director level. Seems like there is a"ceiling" and people get frustrated at this level as they spend a lot of time at this level. Microsoft looses good talent due to this issue as people switch employers.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft

summary: "My least favorite company I've worked for"

cons: Poor management and ambiguous work environment. Health insurance used to be good, but is very expensive now.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 5 years
pros:

Salary
Brand
Microsoft works on various technologies and areas and you are bound to get interested in something
Own office (Probably a con)
cons:
Politics
Microsoft is still in old world top-down thinking. The amount of influence you get to do things in other start up and competing companies is huge. Microsoft doesnt give you that kind of influence. it is improving under Satya. 
But it will take time to seep down. (problem with top-down)

Good if you are fresher (again you are missing out a lot of learning from startup world or from competing companies with great collabaration)
advice_management: Grow up. Let employees have end to end influence over customer experience.

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 10 years

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 8 years

main_text: I worked at Microsoft full-time for more than a year

main_text: I have been working at Microsoft full-time for more than 3 years
pros: The people, benefits, learning opportunities, challenging situations, and everyday growth make one  year of experience working for Microsoft equal to three years of experience working anywhere else.
cons: Forced attrition - a few good people leave each year because they're the lowest performers on the team.  That doesn't mean that they're bad performers - it just means they didn't have a good year.  So, often times, the culture is one of "fear" - "who's next?"
advice_management: Eliminate forced attrition to get better ideas, encourage people to take risks rather than "play it safe" to keep their jobs.
